output: Thank you, Mr. President. I greatly welcome the approach outlined in the White Paper, which seeks to identify the root causes of malnutrition and obesity, and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, we are falling into a very one-sided approach, whether we are discussing nutrient profiles, food labeling, or, in some cases, the White Paper.
We are, in effect, attempting to resolve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
I believe that it is a fundamentally flawed political approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.

Many change requests demonstrate this.
That does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or alternatively, balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of inadequate nutrition are multifaceted.
To remedy this by attempting to guide consumers through product labeling or even through advertising bans or regulations, or by implementing different VAT rates, will not lead us to the goal.

I believe that everything we do here—I don’t want to preempt the debate on the labeling regulation—but everything we do should be framed under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their eating habits?

A traffic light labeling system that suggests to him, "I am now facing a good or bad product," is, in my estimation, more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I desire a more balanced approach here and the realization that we will not be moving forward with product policy alone. Thank you.

Madam President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues,

The budgetary control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the established practices and would also be content with advancements to those established practices.
Five points, first and foremost, our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in establishing the rule of law, justice, and financial oversight.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years' time, and therefore this point is very, very important to us.
The second point: The reliability statement for the overall budget according to the tiered control procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be desirable if we could achieve decisive progress in the remaining six months of the Commission’s term, or at the very least agree on a common path forward.
One becomes modest as a budgetary controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We must provide greater assistance to the member states’ lower levels of administration in the implementation of EU law.
It becomes apparent that they are completely overwhelmed by large portions of EU law, which explains the high error rates.
The fourth point: External assistance. Here, I would like to address primarily the case of Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been in Kosovo. I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budgetary discharge.
I believe that we have remained far below the possibilities of the European Union thus far and that we urgently need to follow up on this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in combating fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the members of the council.

The parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for fraud prevention, in November, and then we must collectively consider how to proceed if we wished to achieve better results in this field.
That has been our shared desire, at least, until now.
Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, particularly also at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief note on this: it also has significance for the Commission’s legislative programme, about which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need sound safety regulations—regulations that deliver results, and not mere window dressing.
It would therefore be a sensible, genuinely necessary measure to finally abolish the nonsensical liquid regulations and devise something better.
I voted in favor of the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled by the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of opposition as well as civil society.
At the same time, we have today urged the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens upon entry into the Schengen Area, thereby preventing a growing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like, first of all, to object to the spirit of a statement heard only a few minutes ago, that foreigners would inundate the labor market, our labor market.
Secondly, I would have preferred a clearer, more definitive report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the European Union’s capacity for social cohesion can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the Court of Justice of the European Union and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms and internal market freedoms.
That changes nothing. Social basic rights are, just like personal freedoms, human rights that must not be restricted by flexibilities of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU Treaties.
It is time to amend the Posting Directive so that requirements for wages and minimum standards may not be limited to minimum requirements.
Mr. President. I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur, Doris Pack, which has already been expressed by many colleagues, and quite rightly so.
We have with her someone who, hopefully, won't pour their heart and soul into it, but who will invest a great deal of passion into this space.
I am pleased with her and the colleagues who also said so, that there have been some advancements, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in reasonable ways.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly point out to our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal more needs to be contributed by them, by their side, and perhaps more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal collaboration among ethnic groups, is something that we must consistently demand.
It is not a matter of everyone attempting to forge their own path.
And inclusion in the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has.
We need to ensure that it is reduced in size.
In this context, the citizens' representative has an important role to play, particularly when and where they perform it effectively.
It is primarily also about reckoning with the engagement and judiciousness of the citizens’ representative.
It is about ensuring that we do not raise expectations that cannot then be met.

It is also, on the other hand, about ensuring that wherever irregularities have occurred within the administrative bodies of the European Union, they are addressed and, wherever possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can guarantee and satisfy citizens.
Past practice has demonstrated that the citizen’s representative undertakes this task with seriousness and diligence.
We can only hope that this remains the case, and we thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Yes.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks collapse or are propped up with billions from the state budget, sales plummet, and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, also the prevailing politics appear incapable of learning from their mistakes.
We are also of the opinion – and we do not wish to unduly emphasize this – that grave errors were committed in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such an error is the structural divergence of money and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing taxation and expenditure policy at least to some degree.
I believe that the economic imbalances within the Eurozone have intensified considerably.
What we need now is, in fact, better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, furthermore, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally controlled again.
We see a second serious error in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who believes a consolidation of households is unavoidable in times like these clearly lives in a different world. Nothing would be more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis now with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has definitively proven its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe is necessary.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for the democratic oversight of the European Central Bank, and furthermore, we demand a revision of the ECB’s monetary policy mandate, whereby growth and employment must, in the future, be promoted at least equally with price stability.
The present crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be lightly squandered.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, esteemed colleagues. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further accelerated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And therefore, we need European solutions for this key European industry to manage the crisis.
Almost all automotive corporations have European structures.

To make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars—as has been mentioned several times here today—and to implement environmentally sound and low-consumption technologies, automakers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
However, the supplier industry—this too must not be forgotten.
Particularly in the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the previous plenary session, the President of the Council proposed protecting key industries.
A good suggestion, as I see it. If one consistently thinks this suggestion through to the end, it means a Volkswagen law for the entire European automobile industry.
and this would certainly be a useful instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being challenged by the European Commission.

And given my question to the Commission: Will the European Commission maintain its course on a legal action despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or is this course being altered in light of the crisis?

Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr. Vice-President of the European Commission, esteemed colleagues,

Indeed, it has become something of a tradition to observe,
You may, in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level, repeatedly fail to receive a statement of assurance.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Court of Audit, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures in place, it is simply not possible to provide a declaration of reliability.
Therefore, we should consider together how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of reliability, if justified, can also be achieved.
And here, of course, we must already distinguish a few things from one another.
First, a household comprising approximately ninety-five subsidies is significantly more susceptible to fraud than a national household or a regional or municipal household.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states – who, in the new funding period, have very much demanded greater autonomy from us – because the criticism of the previous funding period was that it was too centrally controlled.
That naturally also means that responsibility for the money must be assumed regionally and nationally.
And a third area of topic I would like to address briefly.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These, too, are things that are often lumped together.
I, too, am annoyed when EU funds are used to support things that are not strictly necessary.
That was not fraud, that was wastefulness.

Therefore, those who have responsibility for projects, particularly in the area of structural policy, also have a responsibility to the member states to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects are supported which genuinely create added value for the region.
Therefore, we should certainly also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
If member states have to repay, then they only fund what they truly need. Thank you very much.
It is not only I who find it difficult to concur with this burgeoning self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
goes, because if the EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to address the question of responsibility and how all of this could have come about.
It simply isn't true that all the problems we now face are a tsunami, something dictated by natural law, but rather are made by human hands.
And amidst all the regulatory zeal unleashed by this Union, one wonders why action was not taken, to a significant extent, when banks began to cross national borders?
Why was no action taken despite appropriate warnings as the derivatives infiltrated the system?
I recall very well that you, Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz, addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must begin, because recognizing one’s own errors is fundamentally the key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen. Commissioner, my question concerns your opinion on the introduction of the euro as a second currency in Iceland and Hungary.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks’ equity?
My third question is: don't you think a reduction in value-added tax would correspondingly support imports, particularly from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our employees to pay investment premiums, and to correspondingly adjust the progressive depreciation into the
The focus is on increasing primarily low-value assets by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the funds remain within the enterprises, and wages can therefore also be paid better.
Madam President. The comprehensive report highlights how many human rights violations occur around the world every day.
This is particularly alarming sixty years after the proclamation of the Charter of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
For this reason, I would also like to advocate for the current Subcommittee on Human Rights to be established as the main committee.
Today, we have awarded the Sakharov Prize to Anhu Jia, who campaigns for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is currently detained, he could not take possession of it personally.
Shame for China, and tomorrow there will be a debate here on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must prioritize not only economic interests, but above all, human rights.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues,

As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting observations, such as the fact that everyone talks about anti-fraud measures but then nobody does anything.
or the experience of member states calculating their payments to the European Union with a sharp pencil, but loosening their purse strings when it comes to spending that money.
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, because it still takes an average of thirty-six months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fraud prevention system that also includes preventative measures.
We want the Member States to make fraud prevention a priority and that we discuss together the necessities and problems associated with it.
We aim for greater engagement from national judicial authorities in the prosecution of findings from OLAF investigations.
In cases of encroachment, there must no longer be legal vacuums as there have been previously.
We require parity between European currency and national currency.
We want an independent office that possesses the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work noiselessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our statement regarding the legal basis addresses all of these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation as a core element of the Office for Countering Fraud, together with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our observations and to initiate discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We aim to bring about a resolution to the problems of OLAF.
I thank all factions of this Chamber for supporting this, as well, in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I urge the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up and return the Parliament’s ball.
We have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group into our proposals.
From our side, I am authorized to express our interest in a swift conclusion of this regulation and to assure you of our willingness to engage in constructive discussions based on our proposals.
A consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon celebrate his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
For that, combating fraud is too important to us.
We intend, therefore, to realize what is feasible now in collaboration with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President. I would like to address a remark that my Austrian colleague, Paul Rübig, mentioned earlier.

We spend less than one percent of European gross domestic product on Europe, and at the same time, we demand that an ever-increasing number of tasks for an ever-increasing number of member states be handled by the European Union.
This calculation cannot work out. It is therefore also truly implausible that we have pursued a policy of austerity for many years, but austerity not only in the economical
to utilize our funds, but fundamentally to ensure that, at the end of the year, the finance ministers once again reclaim the money and channel it into their respective budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not truly budgetarily funded in years.
I believe that the European Union’s information funding needs to be significantly increased if we genuinely want to connect European citizens to Europe.
And there are numerous tasks within the realm of student and trainee exchange that Europe could undertake here.
that democracy is also advancing in the judicial sector, a sphere previously traditionally reserved for the state.
This corresponds to the altered living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this observation has been made repeatedly. Integration must not intrude too deeply into traditionally established and, above all, functioning structures.
Not everything should be swept under the rug.
Public documents and public officials are structured quite differently in many Member States.
In Austria, but not exclusively in our country, the notary public as a public authority has a long tradition and a high level of security and trustworthiness.
This must not be risked unnecessarily, simply because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness, yes, but with discretion.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. Plant protection products were and remain essential operational resources in the agricultural sector.
Farmers require a minimum selection of crop protection products, as it concerns the preservation of the native cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the protection of resources.
We discuss chemicals far too often on a very irrational level.
To obtain sensible results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal: a broad prohibition of pesticides, leading to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the Three-Zone Regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent solution for the internal market would look different here. Besides the acceptable compromises, we should not anticipate a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances, but rather actually allow the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be overextending the precautionary principle at this point.
Finally, I find it regrettable that we have not been able to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement reached at this time. Thank you very much.
When, during a visit by a head of government or head of state, similar expressions of opinion occurred last time, the President of this House intervened decisively.
At that time, the matter concerned something that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
If today the duly elected president of a country speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
That is not democracy; that is arbitrary rule, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
Madam President. Children and politics rarely see the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so greatly.
For citizens across Europe, the issue of childhood is of paramount importance.
For politicians, children’s concerns rank among distant considerations, as we can observe again here.
I know of no country that has its own ministry for children, nor does the Commission have its own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In Parliament, the topic of childhood has been dispersed across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to particularly highlight to the Commission at this point that today it is addressing childcare facilities and the Barcelona Goals.
Within our parliamentary working group Equality of Childhood, we have observed the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is entirely uncertain.
A child of today can climb to the very top of the social scale or fall to the very bottom.
It can remain within its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
It can chart a similar life course as its parents or do precisely the opposite.
One may marry someone of the opposite or same gender.
All of that was more than fifty years ago, when we launched the unified Europe, quite different.
The diversity that characterizes us Europeans has become a defining factor in children's lives.
The concept of diversity must therefore find its way into the pedagogy of childcare providers and teachers.
This is currently far too little considered.
European childcare facilities and schools are struggling with the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we must press the reset button, back to the start.
Let us approach this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto “Unity through Diversity.”

Furthermore, I ask all succeeding Members of the European Parliament: do not advocate for gender mainstreaming alone, but also champion child mainstreaming, particularly during this time of global financial crisis, lest we burden our children with immeasurable debt.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to send out just two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to express my explicit thanks to the Commissioner for not having spoken fundamentally against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is neither a monstrosity nor a bureaucratic leviathan.
He is a problem-solving tool to which we should give a chance.
Therefore, I would like to use this opportunity to advocate for it once again.
The second thing I’d like to say, and this is directed now to my British friends, across all parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that one might prioritize a country's energy security for a certain period over adherence to an air pollutant limit.
I have considerable understanding of that.
I am also the last person who would deny Your Majesty additional time when it comes to constructing new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it, can’t we?
The problem is, we didn't do precisely that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to remain open-minded at this point during the second reading and to say, "Let's discuss a compromise at this juncture."

for which I must relinquish the completely irrational resistance—resistance that is neither justified from a competition policy or environmental policy perspective—the fundamental opposition to minimum standards.
I believe that at this point, we’ve reached the juncture where a compromise can be achieved, which I hope we will also secure in the second reading at the end.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should avoid seeking a compromise in a first reading.
For this, the legislation is too complex.
I do not wish to conclude this parliamentary term as rapporteur and leave the next parliament with legislation involving a text that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I request your support for the compromises when we vote in one hour.

Dear colleagues,

The crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programs being finalized across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
Will banks be issued further blank checks, even though the rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer?
And should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved, despite having already been pampered for years across Europe through tax breaks?

The more money is squandered for such purposes, the more predictable the failure of these programs becomes, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalization – precisely this policy – has increasingly concentrated income among the top ten percent, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Anyone who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue precisely this policy with minor modifications simply doesn’t understand anything at all.
The precise opposite is needed.
Instead of purchasing toxic assets from banks, tax revenue should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and for the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be the case that taxpayer money is not allocated without employment guarantees and, above all, without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, particularly, the general public can participate in future revenues.
The very best economic stimulus program that currently exists would be a radical redistribution of income and assets from the top down.
The sector of exploitative wages in Europe must be curtailed, rather than further encouraged.
We need higher minimum wages; we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who, after all, never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I believe that what is socially just is presently also the economically most sensible.
And it is the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamic.

Mr. President. At the beginning of March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow, to be indicted again on the basis of untenable charges.
The first day of public proceedings was scheduled for March thirty-first.
On the same day, human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important discussions have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia thereby demonstrates very clearly the low value it places on human rights.
The judiciary will continue not only to fail to deliver justice, but to be employed for the elimination of regime opponents, thereby deceiving the EU.
Mr. President. Thank you very much, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again addressing the prohibition of animal experimentation.

because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to cosmetics legislation that I have been privileged to witness, the sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
We have, in fact, managed to prohibit animal experimentation.
We have managed to ensure that, for example, consumers know how long a product remains shelf-stable by seeing a small container with a number indicating its remaining validity period.

I also say this, addressing some colleagues, particularly my colleague Reuthofer, who unfortunately was not present at the beginning: markings are never warnings at any time. If a product were not safe, then it may not be on the market, then it may not be marketed.
Every product present on this European market must be safe and without risk.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
This is democracy, and this is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have endeavored to design the procedure in a very transparent manner.
I have attempted, as Ms. Kostet also mentioned, to reconcile differing opinions.

For I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for all, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that must work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
I reiterate my agreement to colleague Schnellhardt: yes, DEO affects everyone differently, but the statement that it keeps them sweat-free is nonetheless made.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my crease depth around the eyes are also quite realistic and reliable after one week in Strasbourg.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the commissioner, also regarding the explanations he provided, to my colleagues, and to my assistant, who did the majority of the work.
I thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. The report by Mr. Van Nistelrooy concerning the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is undoubtedly one of the most significant of the Board of Directors in recent years.
We endorse the fundamental concept of the Green Paper, according to which territorial cohesion is essentially about fostering the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall as well as a sustainable development of the territories with diverse characteristics and specific features, while simultaneously preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period a more comprehensive system of phased support for transition regions, exceeding a threshold of seventy-five
must be created so that these regions receive a distinct status and thus have greater security in their development.
And in the report by Colleague Kreh regarding obstacles to the drawdown of Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings faced by applicants in the
eligible for funding from structural funds, such as excessive administrative burden, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the member states.
And numerous recommendations are made to the Commission regarding the measures that should be taken to reduce these obstacles.
I would simply like to single out and reiterate two such measures.

Firstly, project managers are currently required to retain their project documentation for a period of ten years, in order to have it available for inspections that may be conducted by the Commission.
Especially for smaller projects, it represents an excessively bureaucratic undertaking.
Indeed, that is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission’s assessment criteria for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
In innovative projects, different evaluation criteria than those used for other projects are not permissible.
It is simply necessary that something else occur here.

Madam President. When Europe invests money, and when, above all, the member states invest a great deal of money to assist the automotive industry in its crisis situation, then it cannot be solely about securing existing structures and the status quo and preventing plant closures, but rather about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about enabling people to seek employment, ensuring they secure that employment, and doing so on a long-term basis.
For this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all, sustainability within the transport system more strongly than we have done previously.

Therefore, we should link all our measures to these objectives, so that we are not forced to acknowledge in a few years' time that we should have considered all of this many years ago – if we had done so, we would not be facing the next and new crisis.
Madam President. It would be appreciated if you would also grant me the additional half-minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had submitted a sound proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments seek to supplement this proposal with stipulations that are incompatible with the objectives of the regulation or even intend to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and welfare of animals would simply overwhelm retailers.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO legislation, namely the demand for special labeling of novel foods derived from animals fed with genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it.
Generally, everything that pertains to GMO legislation should not be addressed within the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this, although I myself, for example, had submitted a proposal to specifically delineate certain new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be the case that interested parties within this institution are abusing the Novel Food Regulation for electoral campaign purposes.
This appears to also be the case with amendment proposals two and ninety-nine, for which the Green Party has requested a roll-call vote.
Gentlemen, what exactly are you trying to expose?
My faction, too, has consistently advocated for the consumer’s right to know what is contained in foodstuffs.
Why, then, shouldn’t the declaration of ingredients indicate a nano origin?
And although amendment sixty-two rather clumsily attempts to preempt my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of Novel Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend to my parliamentary group that they approve the aforementioned proposals, and I will include in my report on the food labelling regulation references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labelling.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labeling to the next legislative period, against the wishes of the Green Party.
But now it is evident to everyone how advantageous this postponement proved to be.
Briefly regarding cloning, it is animal cruelty.
We are opposed to it.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be incorporated into this regulation accordingly, otherwise they will no longer function within a legal framework.
Madam President. It is very simple.
Whoever does not wish for this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament should support my proposal to amend the Rules of Procedure. Thank you.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues.

One thing must be stated clearly: the provision of food to those in need, particularly during these economically challenging times, is not open to debate in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Sikerski.
Therefore, I would also like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our parliamentary group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each colleague in our group to deviate from this course and to not agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?

There are a number of reasons for this, which have absolutely nothing, not even the slightest thing, to do with assisting those in need within the European Union during these economically challenging times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE Group, though unfortunately not deemed admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable footing.
For the current system is an anachronism from times of agricultural overproduction, which thankfully belongs to the past.

Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily declined in recent years, meaning that today up to eighty-five percent of food must be repurchased on the open market.
That, however, fundamentally altered the character of the program and resulted in the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
Since we are now dealing with a social program, however, we must establish a corresponding legal basis for it.
We hereby share the assessment of the Council's legal service, which, instead of Article thirty-seven of the EC Treaty concerning the common agricultural policy, merely
Article 308 is considered a legal basis, because otherwise it would clearly constitute an infringement on the member states’ national competence.
The only possible solution, given the inadmissibility of our proposed amendments, can be a new draft from the European Commission.
It should continue to uphold the principle of co-financing, for only on-site can the sense and nonsense of such programs be adequately assessed to the satisfaction of all.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, we too welcome the proposal of the European Commission and this Green Paper in principle.
There exists a mass phenomenon, as described by the various previous speakers, where relatively minor damage occurs affecting a large number of people.
The damage to those directly affected is small, but when aggregated overall, it is substantial.
An instrument is needed to address this problem.
It is, in my view, also correct to reflect upon such matters.

I also highly welcome – in the interest of maintaining a positive tone – that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This represents a significant difference from the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here yesterday, and which has hitherto completely disregarded the possibility of extrajudicial dispute resolution mechanisms.
I believe that here, the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection goes further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I want to make two things quite clear as well, which, in my estimation, should certainly be understood as critical observations.
The Parliament will adopt my report on the Directorate-General for Competition's White Paper in a few minutes, at twelve o’clock.
We will demand, with an overwhelming majority in this House, from the European Commission that a horizontal approach be chosen when addressing this matter.
It cannot be the case that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for antitrust law, another for the capital market, perhaps even one for the environment.

Perhaps one more for Social [policy], and they all contradict each other, all intervening in the legal order of the member states and ultimately leading to a legislative quagmire that no practitioner can any longer manage.
We have often had such examples in the past.
I am only thinking about the debate concerning the professional qualifications directive, which we subsequently compiled into an instrument, because this fragmentation had become unsustainable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote a horizontal approach from the outset.
That is the clear position of the Parliament; that will become clear here in a few months, in a few minutes.

One final point. I also greatly welcome the fact that we have achieved a consensus that we do not want a litigation industry modeled after the American system, generating $240 billion in revenue annually, where ultimately only lawyers profit and the consumer gains nothing.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.
Esteemed colleagues, there are many ways to manage the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure within the European recovery program, is designed as a good response—albeit not entirely sufficient—but first and foremost as a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical, situation.
This also involves promoting greater simplification of procedures and increased flexibility in the application of existing
Provisions within the framework of the Structural Funds Regulation, following a request, dear colleagues, which the European Parliament has repeatedly made in recent years.

It is also to be welcomed, and I would like to emphasize this in particular, that an amendment to Article seven will enable the Member States and regions of the EU to be placed in a position to fund expenses concerning
to invest in structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in the housing sector, and that these measures should not be limited to households with low incomes.

The related amendment therefore rightly removes the line on households with low incomes and instead introduces a ceiling of four percent of the total EFRE allocation for each member state for such expenditure.
This is just one of many proposed improvements.
In short, the realization of this overall package results in an acceleration of expenditures and, consequently, further liquidity for the execution of necessary
Requirements deriving from Structural Funds, namely ERDF, ESF, and Cohesion Funds, and a simplification of regulations to enable rapid program implementation.
a meaningful, albeit insufficient, contribution to managing the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. In principle, I welcome the European Ecolabel.
It is correct that we are making a new effort to further disseminate this community's environmental label.
I also believe it is correct that we should adhere to voluntariness in the future.
The sign will only gain acceptance in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that precede its acquisition.
Here, I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, and comprehensible criteria.
The incentive concept must be paramount.
It would be regrettable if the establishment of the eco-label were to fail due to bureaucratic obstacles.
Ultimately, success or failure hinges on the consumer, as acceptance must be achieved with them.

Even though I am personally very fond of the Blue Angel ecolabel we have in Germany, it must ultimately not be a matter of personal preference, but rather it is essential to convey to the consumer at a glance what special properties a product has.
A benefit for the consumer arises only when the member states relinquish their respective national marks and a single mark ultimately exists at the European level.
A flurry of symbols unsettles the consumer and does not inform them.
A sign, a statement. For that, we should work together.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that we have made some progress together during this legislative term, regarding the discharge procedure of the European institutions.

I do regret, however, that it took so long, as we have essentially only now processed everything that had already become apparent with the commission’s resignation in nineteen ninety-nine – that is, ten years ago.

This demonstrates that we still need to refine our working methods and procedures, and ensure that the necessary transparency is achieved more swiftly when it comes to informing citizens how tax revenues are being utilized.
I would like to express my particular gratitude to my colleague, Mr. Kazaka, with whom I had the honor of working for the EPP Group on the parliamentary discharge of responsibility.

I very much regret that I have just taken a quick look to see that a colleague, who frequently comments extensively on press matters concerning the European Parliament, has not participated in either the committee consultations, the committee votes, nor in this plenary debate.
I want to state this very clearly at this point, so that it is preserved and remains preserved for posterity. We are very well aware that there have been a number of problems here.

We were and are, and it was the Members of Parliament who are present here now who ensured that the necessary reforms were achieved in a variety of areas in the interest of the Members of Parliament over the last five years.
For this, our heartfelt thanks to everyone. We have done what was necessary, and we have not ensured that everything is widely publicized in the media but without any collaboration.
For this, a thank you for the reliable collaboration.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen. The AUDIT report – heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur – truly moves us forward, because it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted critique instead of sweeping accusations.
That it is precisely the socialist faction that is now backing down and would prefer to sweep the truth under the rug is a scandal and a disservice to our oversight responsibilities.
The credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow that to happen.
A word about our biggest problem children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission’s failure in preparing for the accessions becomes most evident here.
We have lost a great deal of money.
The Commission has long observed and only in 2008 froze funds for Bulgaria, now exceeding one billion euros, for Romania approximately 102 million euros.
Freezing assets is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve the name.
Here, the Audi report proposes how things could be improved.
The EU Commission misled Parliament regarding the accession readiness of these countries, and the Enlargement Commissioner should, in fact, draw consequences from this.
However, our concern is the management of future accessions, and therefore this topic remains on the agenda.
Our faction will release the discharge to the Commission, but I personally will deny the discharge to the Commission.
Unfortunately, the commission's zeal for reform, which one could again have discerned a small glimmer of last year, has already fizzled out.
Stagnation in fraud prevention, nothing on the topic of prevention, ethics not desired, etc.
The Commission, and Commissioner Kallas in particular, should be clear about one thing if it wishes to secure the Parliament’s support.
Mr. President. Yes, we have a problem with copyright and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and that is where we must also become active and do something.
But when we become active, it is about genuinely responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
I will explain to you why I arrive at this word.
The proposal before us essentially fulfills only one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
When we come to what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we also
Such low average sums, that it in no way serves as a livelihood for an artist, enabling them to make anything of it.
Moreover, this money does not reach the artists directly.
and the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist with whom I discussed this has told me that here a redistribution is taking place from the living to the dead.
I had to contradict him. It is a redistribution of funds from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and specifically to the major players.
All in all, Mr. Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We must find better ones.
We need to create something like a flag rate, for example.
Even the suggestions you make regarding the use it or lose it clause remain theoretical law.
Let us produce something clever and well-founded, as the artists in our hearing in the Legal Committee recommended and requested.
Mr. President. I share the Rapporteur Gilles Sabery’s regret that the Commission has abandoned its original plan for a comprehensive action plan.
There are many good reasons why all stakeholders, from the municipalities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
Therefore, the fundamental agreement with the plan and the report of the colleague Savary, to develop corresponding integrated proposals here from the initiative of the Parliament.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the specific suggestions.
At the same time, however, I want to signal with utmost clarity that what many fear or believe they must fear will not occur.
No one wishes to deny municipalities, or local and regional administrative bodies, their right to shape their transportation conditions.
From the European side, we simply want to contribute to ensuring that proceedings follow sensible, common rules when a municipality, a city, or a regional unit deems this reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not jeopardized.
What we aim to do here is to safeguard this principle.
It therefore remains that we, in the interest of citizens, strive to ensure that not, when a citizen travels ten, twenty kilometers in Europe…
Europe continues, and he encounters a traffic-calmed zone which he believes he knows from his home community, only to find entirely different rules applying there.

No one will impose any municipal duties or other regulations on any communities, but if they are actually implemented here, then they should be enacted for the citizens within a discernible framework.
For more than a hundred years, we have agreed on the sense of common approaches regarding traffic signs.
That should also be the case with this topic in the future.
Mr. President. We have now been dealing with urban transport within the EU for quite some time.
Why actually?

We are simply not responsible. Jurisdiction was originally established because approximately eighty percent of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, there is now a desire to address the matter.
Well, fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission to an action plan for urban mobility through our protest.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his understanding.
Subsidere does indeed, more accurately, mean to support rather than to prescribe, but he, as an Italian, naturally knows that better than I, as a German with only a single, significant Latin degree.
It is primarily important to me that our report, the report of Parliament, highlights the strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are impermissible for urban traffic.

Supportive measures.
That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is beneficial.
Not everyone needs to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailored solutions, but these can only be developed by the actors on site, for only they know what is necessary.
Municipalities must cater to very different circumstances. They therefore require sufficient scope for action, also in order to maintain the vibrancy of inner-city retail.
That is important for the appeal of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual transport and to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research on intra-urban crime distribution supported.
That alleviates a city’s burden.
It is also important to consider demographic change.
Our society is ultimately growing older.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need provision of everyday goods for the population close to where they live if we want to reduce traffic reduction, and that is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Everything else would only demand the green meadow.
Finally, we do not need a traffic observation point for the urban area.
Such a position would cost a great deal of money and produce a significant amount of paperwork, which would be filed solely in Brussels. Thank you very much.
Madam President. I fully support the Commission’s objective of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated deployment and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle to achieve the standard introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, underscores the urgency for me almost daily. Yet, intelligent transport systems can do much more.
They contribute to environmental compatibility, efficiency gains, enhanced safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support multimodality, among other things, through the development of interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air transport, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a task of common responsibility.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide, legally binding fundamental standards and regulations regarding minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning certainty, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned, open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transportation system services.

The action plan now includes a timeline for the introduction of individual systems a for road traffic safety, such as ESP and eCall, b for continuity in traffic management; for example, information on
Avoid toll charges or parking management and traffic congestion? c The utilization of road, traffic, and travel data in real time will benefit not only professional drivers but all road users.
The Directive aims to establish detailed requirements for the uniform, EU-wide, and coordinated implementation of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.

However, caution: The introduction of intelligent transportation systems incurs high costs, as infrastructure and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We know too little yet about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. We unequivocally support assistance for individuals with rare diseases.
However, amendment fifteen is ethically entirely unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe regarding life that is worth living and life that is not.
In Europe, there must be no political or social pressure on parents to consciously decide against a child with a disability.
The selection of embryos would represent a significant ethical breach.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not sufficient to merely eliminate the word that unfortunately corresponds to fascist language—shriehen.
but it would still be a matter of selection of embryos.
And it would be unbearable if this proposed amendment, which refers to a selection of end-embryos, were thus to become a stirrup for a new ethics in Europe.
We must decisively oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our faction would unfortunately also be compelled to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Mr. President. In the vote on the discharge of responsibilities, I voted against the discharge for the Commission for the first time since I have been a member of this House, and I would like to
I would like to explain my reasons. My primary concern is the manner in which the European Commission has handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, including a high level of corruption and a significant amount of European funds that have disappeared.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in the year two thousand and eight.
We lost two thousand seven [year] a significant amount of money and are now dealing with either scarcely available control systems or systems that function only incompletely.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems within the judiciary.
All of this is attributable to the pre-accession process.

My aim is to set a precedent, to also tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently regarding future accessions, and to indicate that, as has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly achieve greater success if it so wishes.
I would like to urge the Commission to assist both countries in establishing financial control systems that live up to their name and to eliminate the systemic weaknesses in those two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a persistent problem and a perpetual burden for all of Europe.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area designated for far-right sympathizers, there are individuals who are not Members of Parliament, and as far as I can see, they are indeed marking ballots.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhard’s draft report and thank him for his excellent work.
Following the numerous crises of recent years related to products of animal origin that pose a risk to human and animal health, a comprehensive legal framework is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We must still ensure a high level of security.
Although we generally agree with the report, I see several points that give me cause for thought.
The regulation has been eased in many respects, thereby slightly relaxing trade in animal by-products.
Some examples: There is a permit for the use of certain materials from category one in pet food.
Materials of category two or three can be disposed of with facilitated handling under official supervision, regardless of their risk, when the weekly waste quantity is low.
However, the risk associated with animal by-products of any category is determined only in part by their quantity.
It remains the case that the European Commission will issue the implementing regulation, and the draft, as previously, contains numerous enabling powers for the Commission.

That is to say, the Commission can adopt comprehensive and fundamental regulations concerning the handling of animal by-products through the comitology procedure. This means that Parliament, as unfortunately often occurs, is excluded. Thank you.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Afghanistan has a difficult history behind it.
I believe that the families there hold together particularly strongly and that the woman in the family plays an important role.
Therefore, economic development is particularly important, namely, support for small and medium-sized enterprises should be promoted especially strongly.
And it is, of course, also necessary to have a modern infrastructure that helps the country to develop more easily.

I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help to foster a greater understanding between people, and naturally, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly gain traction there, while fully respecting identity.

The pollution of the oceans is only ever at the center of attention when there has been another spectacular incident, and then there is also intense discussion about the threat to our oceans from this constant pollution.
But unfortunately, this then recedes increasingly into the background in the meantime.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the suffering of not only our oceans but also our coastlines, were to be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues, with whom we were able to discuss, for consistently upholding the line that our sea must be protected.
I speak here as a member of a landlocked nation, yet as a European, I feel the responsibility to protect our seas from permanent pollution for the sake of cheap economic gains.
to protect interests and to integrate the principles of the second maritime package and the third maritime package, which is urgently necessary, as the Legal Committee has also proposed.
Madam President, colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Obiol Sidjama, on his very good report.
Worldwide, the respect for human rights is very poor in many countries.
But also here in Europe, if we consider Belarus, for example.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly strengthen its efforts by implementing human rights policy into all areas and establishing clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can, for example, occur during negotiations for a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause that has influence across all negotiation areas.
I would also like to reiterate my advocacy for the Subcommittee on Human Rights to be elevated to a full committee.
Okay. The EPP D faction calls on the government and the Communist Party of China to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly ease the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
We will have to maintain our justified demands regarding China.
Therefore, from our perspective, the civil rights activist should be released immediately.
Thus, the conversations with the Dalai Lama, as the religious leader of Tibet, can be resumed.
And so, the Chinese region of Tibet is to be made immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China demonstrated prior to the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without jeopardizing the country’s stability.
Now she should have the courage to address new reforms—reforms concerning re-education camps, rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, and freedom of assembly.
These human rights should genuinely concern her, and she should engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President. Regarding today’s decision by the Czech Senate, which we warmly welcome and heartily congratulate,
President Klaus reacted, among other things, by asserting that the Lisbon Treaty was nevertheless dead, having been rejected through the referendum in Ireland.

Thus, he rides like a political zombie, launching an attack against majority decisions of his own parliament and senate, and thereby confirming his infamous and sectarian stance in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, he only makes himself look ridiculous after the positive votes.
We Greens view the European integration process positively and constructively, of course also with critical remarks where necessary.
Once again, heartfelt thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament, and the government.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. Last week, we heard Mr. Mahmalbaf in the Foreign Affairs Committee, which was convened, to my delight, with my induction as a new member.

an Iranian film director, who made it very clear to us that there were twenty democracies in Iran before this election, but after this election, which he considers a coup, there are no democracies left whatsoever.

I too endorse this designation. It was indeed a coup d'état by election, which, through massive electoral fraud, deprived the majority of the Iranian population—those who had voted for change—of their right.
Mr. President, what interests me above all is this: there will be an inauguration ceremony for the so-called re-elected Mr. Ahmadinejad in mid-August.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and with the Member States?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the Member States here?
I hope there will be none of those, because I believe that after this electoral coup, there should be no official representation of the European Union or of the
Member states may participate, and while I advocate for further dialogue, no one from the European Union should be officially represented at this inauguration.
What is your position on this?
How is this currently being handled? Thank you.
Mr. Giegold, one minute. The crisis in Europe was not brought about solely by unethical behavior in the financial markets, Mr. Barroso.
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and unsolidary macroeconomic imbalances between member states, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that repeatedly places these underlying causes on the agenda, rather than tabooing them, rather than doing the opposite, rather than shifting responsibility to the Member States.
We need genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need fiscal cooperation in Europe that ends tax dumping.
Only then does it become possible to halt social divisions and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles to the extent that the EU's dependence on finite resources declines sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I don’t find any of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is the reason why I cannot choose you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. Barroso, imagine you are a great man.
would face an election in Europe, just you alone, no other candidate—how many votes would you receive?
What would the citizens do?
You would likely have listened today and seen that you have promised everyone everything.
You would hopefully also receive the information regarding what you did five years ago.
You have promised a great deal, a very great deal.
One must compare what they have promised before, what they are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I believe that is very little.
You represent the old, the failed Europe, the contribution to the financial crisis, because the Commission failed, due to a lack of commitment regarding climate issues, and, and, and.
I would side with the majority of European citizens, because I believe they would not receive more than ten or twelve or fifteen votes.
I would like to advocate for maintaining the new proposal, as it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no joint proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
That is to say, I request that the plenary approve the proposal of the Presidium for this amendment, that the elections be removed.
Democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, Mr. Dartmouth, to advocate for transparency, Mr. Verhofstadt.
And you, particularly now during the Swedish Council Presidency, could indeed serve as a shining example and then truly tell us how things will proceed.
The matter concerns the deeply undignified job-swapping regarding top positions, and in this regard, Mr. Barroso could take the lead in the appointment of the Commissioners.
Germany and Austria provide a negative example, but others do as well.
Qualified individuals are present in this hall, but lack access.

Please be courageous now that the Lisbon Treaty has been ratified, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commissions and the top positions.
And it must become possible to identify capable individuals here from the European Parliament with such expertise and not have to build them up in individual federal states.
Mr. President. The topic we are discussing here this evening has already appeared several times on the agenda of the European Parliament.
It is well known that the Commission bases its grant of assistance on the conditions of the International Monetary Fund.
That has resonated a few times already.
Against this backdrop, there have been repeated inquiries from the EP to the Commission.

The EP requested the Commission in November two thousand eight to submit an analysis of the effects of the behavior of banks that transferred their assets from the member states which had recently acceded.
On the twenty-fourth of April of this year, the EP reiterated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded to be informed of the letters of intent, concluded in detail between the Commission and the Member States receiving aid, which specify the conditions for the aid in detail.
As far as I am aware, these inquiries have not yet been answered.
My first question is therefore: is it correct that these inquiries have not yet been answered?
If that is correct, then my second question is: Why have these requests not been answered to date?
My third question is then: When can I expect a response to these inquiries?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL group will not support this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme sails completely past the actual challenges of the present.
The core error lies in establishing a Europe of rights that is granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
These same citizens and human rights they are not to receive.
On the one hand, the EU wishes to accede to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Thus, Frontex is being bolstered for the massive suppression of so-called irregular migration, and I tell you, this completely obscures the view of an impartial immigration policy.
Here, Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the entirely imbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a negotiable commodity, but a universal right inherent to every human being.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU’s obsession with security, by creating vast supranational databases lacking sufficient oversight mechanisms, which consolidate intelligence and police data across Europe.
This will make the right to informational self-determination of individuals, scrap paper, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.

Allow me, as a Member of Parliament from eastern Germany, to conclude by stating that twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to witness how Europe is increasingly becoming a fortress.

Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, you are correct.
Compared to other modes of transport, the railway system is a very safe system.

Despite many positive aspects, liberalization in the form of societal fragmentation, the separation of infrastructure and operations, the outsourcing of maintenance work, and the leasing of materials and personnel has nevertheless introduced a degree of uncertainty.
It must, in my view, be ensured that national security authorities issue the safety certificates and authorisations in accordance with the regulations of the ERA, the European Railway Agency.
Are there sufficient controls?
For example, it is ensured that the training of personnel, the certifications, and the working conditions are properly monitored.
How does this relate to the introduction of a uniform community certificate?
What is the status of the European train driver's license?
The efforts concerning ERTMS must be further increased.
The recently established, by you indicated implementation plan must be binding and may not be delayed by financial or national considerations.
The efforts regarding the introduction of technical specifications TSI must be continued and expanded.
This would represent a substantial advancement, particularly during material homologation, and would provide a greater level of safety in material maintenance.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near misses can be attributed to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons. For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected, and the intervals of maintenance work are extended.
How does a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops stand here?
It must, in my estimation, be everything possible to avoid each individual member state reverting to its old rules and again acting differently and autonomously.
In particular, border crossings between individual member states pose a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to address this problem in the short term?
And when you prepare the balance sheet, I would like you to be sure to consider the social aspects. Thank you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years now, I have been following your reports in this house, first as a journalist, and ultimately, they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look forward.

Leveraging the subject matter expertise of this institution, which, quite deliberately, has assembled here today in this very hall—I see colleagues Söndergaard, I see colleagues Chaci Makakis, there is Mr. Staas, and from our list, my colleague Mr. Ehrenhauser—reorganize the work of the Court of Audit.
Consider what works elsewhere in Germany, where the efficiency and meaningfulness of expenditures can be examined, in Austria, and develop

Do you perhaps have a concept, within the framework of an initiative report that will then come before Parliament, regarding how to significantly improve what you do, so that you can actually fulfill your tasks?
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates, as we hear them today, already began in this chamber ten years ago.
I would strongly urge you, Madam Commissioner, to really commit to memory, above all, what comes from Arlem Desir, but also from the Greens and from some liberal Members of Parliament.

Do you not realize that with the approach with which the European Union has entered into the negotiations, we cannot remedy the imbalance as an honest broker? I believe that, in conjunction with what we are currently experiencing in Copenhagen in these hours and days, we need a new approach in reality.
Developing countries are no longer developing countries in many respects, regarding what they do today.
Emerging markets, developed countries, and very self-assured.
If it fails to achieve a fresh start with fair conditions from the European side, then we will end up where we do not want to be, namely with protectionism and a 1933-style Europe.
Mr. President. I would like to use the blue card solely for a clarification.
The support in Austria is not granted for only one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those threatened by unemployment, and above all for people who lack access to conventional credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our parliamentary group.
However, what the Commission and Council have achieved in terms of performance in this process is simply inadequate, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism concerns the question of financial provision.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial support for an unemployment reduction program; it cannot be described as a microfinance program, at best it is nanofinance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to performing such conjurer's tricks without any effect, which are at the expense of other programs and therefore dissipate endlessly.
Thirdly, the concept of sustainability and the success of such a program must inherently include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail; therefore, the program must also ensure that this is addressed.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not discontinued for the purpose of accessing this programme, otherwise it will be rendered ineffective.
This cannot sustainably combat unemployment.
