We will reject it in this form.
Mr. President. Today, after eight years, we all essentially know it. The Afghanistan strategy thus far, predicated on a military focus, has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and the inadequate resources for civilian purposes effectively prevents an improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.

We need a radical shift in strategy, away from the military and, above all, toward the people.
That means that forty of the Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in truly dire poverty, lacking both healthcare and adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront, and that is what we expect from the Council, from the Commission, from all stakeholders.
This naturally includes strengthening responsible government action, bolstering agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you, quite honestly, whoever only pursues this path halfway and again resorts to military adventures forfeits every opportunity.

Mr. President. Regional structural promotion measures are an essential instrument in European integration. Particularly, Measure Two promotion has in the past been perceived by people in many regions as a driving force for local structural and economic development.
It is an important element for managing structural change in regions and municipalities.
Here, too, Europe becomes truly tangible for citizens, because it also has an effect on the ground.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the Cohesion Funds, as well as improved controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a key objective within the EU, and therefore we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but rather strengthen it.
Cohesion policy in Europe requires greater clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the individual member states’ accountability.
And therefore, it is important to remain within the system of additive funding.
We do not, however, want a renationalization of structural support.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from two thousand thirteen onwards meet these requirements.

Madam President, it appears to me to be somewhat symptomatic for us, that is, for the EU in general, but also for Parliament in particular, that we reflexively conduct discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
It is unfortunate that overnight events frequently lead to us suddenly outpouring ourselves in political demands, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it is not appropriate for us to initiate a general debate about Yemen solely on the basis of a failed aircraft attack.
I believe that we should be clear with ourselves that it would behoove us to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires careful analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government operates that no longer controls large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise for Europe from this.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging along the coast of Yemen, where piracy is evidently taking place.
Therefore, it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Eschten to consider what we can do to mitigate these risks.
For my part, the question can primarily be: How can we bolster the government in Yemen, regain control of the country, and contain these risks?

All other discussions concerning the long-term development of the country must, of course, also take place, but I do not believe it is truly sensible, nor that we will be taken seriously, if we now initiate a catalogue of demands spanning all policy areas, from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
That will not achieve the objective in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what specific assistance we can provide in the current situation to resolve an acute problem.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen. The massacre of November 23rd of last year in the province of Maguindanao, Philippines, was a dark day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
Seventy-seven dead, raped women, injured people. They speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that thirty journalists were among the deceased.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, never before in any documented case have so many journalists been murdered at once.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we are doing today in the draft resolution.

However, as EPP, we demand that the present text be softened in three places through separate votes, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making remarks that could be construed as accusatory towards the government.
Therefore, I request, on behalf of the EPP, a vote specifically on Recital F. This condemns the Philippines for exhibiting all signs of a non-functioning legal system.
In point two, we would like to remove the assertion of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Ultimately, it is claimed regarding point six that there are missing persons residing in Philippine prisons.
This too is currently an unproven assertion and should, in our opinion, be removed. Thank you.

Madam President. The issue here is that we, as the European Union, must pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively intervene here.
Here, Europe can demonstrate strength as a partner by speaking with a single voice.

Madam President, Commissioner, my esteemed colleagues. Firstly, many thanks to Mr. Leichtfried for an excellent report that continues to convey viable and sound content.

Remarkably, however, it is also noteworthy that in the impact assessment presented to us by the Commission, an amount of approximately 0.1 of the total transport fare is calculated for these measures.
Therefore, we should not begin at too high a level.

Dear Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council,

The evaluation of passenger data is being approached in a manner similar to that employed by SWIFT, in an attempt to combat global terrorism and the
to reconcile serious criminal activity with the fundamental rights of each individual to the protection of privacy and also informational self-determination.
However, we must also be aware that in the age of mobility, both in Europe and worldwide, there will be no sufficient security without effective and rapid data exchange.
In the digital age, we must ensure special protection with regard to informational self-determination and privacy.
I therefore also consider it necessary to distinguish more precisely between the data necessary for combating crime and the data sensitive with regard to privacy.
For me, it is actually not a question at all that we must firmly integrate controls, remedies, access rights, claims for damages, and the duration of storage into the agreement.
When using the push method, it must be examined whether exceptions may or must be permitted in urgent cases.
Regarding the use of passenger data, we should also include serious criminal offenses.
And for me, this includes offenses such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and also drug trafficking.
That, too, would, in my view, be a contribution to the protection of the personal rights of those affected.
I am pleased that we have postponed the decision regarding the disputed passenger data agreements to develop a baseline model for all future agreements of this kind.
We also need to further develop this and, in order to provide the Commission with a framework for negotiations, one that takes our own data protection considerations into account.
Perhaps there will also be an opportunity in the future to consider conducting counter-terrorism and crime prevention efforts jointly with our transatlantic partners in a common institution.
And that would certainly also be a step to confront globalized crime globally. Thank you.
Madam President. The previous speakers were right to highlight the importance of the EIB.

I urge you to proceed accordingly, and I ask my colleagues at the EIB to continue their work, to become even more transparent in the area of transparency, because your practices also assist the emergence of a new fascism that we must combat.
Policy coherence for development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries while simultaneously destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can advocate for better healthcare as much as we like, but if we hinder the trade of generics or drive up drug prices to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And while agrofuels may reduce CO₂ emissions in the EU to a limited extent, they lead to deforestation and land conversion in developing countries, thereby exacerbating climate change – precisely what we are currently attempting to avoid – not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduction in arable land for food production.
Currently, that is to say, the EU as such is not particularly coherent.
That political measures should not contradict each other has long been recognized by the EU in theory.
The Treaty of Lisbon enshrines policy coherence for development.
Article 208 states: When implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take account of the objectives of development cooperation.
We must be prepared to meet this challenge.
This year, we are reviewing progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without political coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must become aware of this responsibility, as must all those who enact and implement laws. Before we adopt any measure, there must be an impact assessment, so that we can even recognize what aspects of European legislation may have negative consequences for developing countries.
We need expertise in advisory bodies, commissions, and parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's policy coherence programme is a good step in this regard.
Now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence for development means that in the fisheries reform, we must give greater consideration to the interests of local people and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing conglomerates.
It means that we must dry up tax havens into which funds drain from developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
Thus far, the Commission has been unable to dismiss this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that when establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the Development Commissioner’s competencies must be expanded, not restricted.
And it is also essential that we, for example, enable Fairtrade procurement in municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rühle has proposed.
In many cases, we must carefully monitor Members of the Commission and the Council to ensure that they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, it also rests with us, the Members of Parliament, to be consistent in the interest of development.
We need to improve coordination between the committees, and we require a permanent rapporteur.
The report, unanimously approved by the Development Committee, makes many good suggestions and brings us a significant step forward.

I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs – both men and women – the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues,

For months, we have been discussing the matter of driving and working hours in road transport.
And I wonder what arguments will now be deployed to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The most recent argument is: We urgently need to change something here, so that nothing changes.
Do you not notice, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argument has become, how it is permeated with lies and half-truths?
This dispute concerns nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
In labor law, the fundamental question for 150 years has been the protection of people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and salaried employees.
It makes absolutely no difference whether it is a self-employed individual feeling overwhelmed, or whether an employer is overworking an employee.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessive working hours, in part also from employers and clients.
Secondly, regarding road safety, it is asserted here that nothing could possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hobby hardware store, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws on the basis of "let's see what comes of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours create a propensity for accidents, particularly in road traffic, with significant consequences.
Third point: Who, then, is to control such a differentiated regulation, which you envision, in the future on our roads?
Today, a regional labor judge cannot verify whether someone appears self-employed or is genuinely self-employed without an extensive review of records.

Leave this nonsense.
It’s about fair competition.
It is not a matter of setting a precedent today for the future dispute regarding the extension of working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.
Madam President. As I have for many years, today I am committed to road safety, to improving the working conditions of our professional drivers, and to enhancing the image of their profession.

Quite clearly, today we are not addressing the traffic safety-relevant regulations concerning driving and rest times, which all self-employed and employed professional drivers must observe; today, we are addressing working time regulation.
It is primarily a worker protection regulation, serving therefore only the social protection of drivers and in no way traffic safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Compliance with working hours is neither controllable with a significant bureaucratic burden for self-employed truck and bus drivers, nor is there a discernible reason for conducting such controls at all.

Restricting self-employed professional drivers, and perhaps in the future also self-employed tradespeople, architects, or members of parliament, in their permissible working hours sends the wrong signal.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. Just a few days ago, we witnessed with shock on television images vast swathes of Poland and other Central European countries submerged by floodwaters.
People have perished in the floods, and our deepest sympathy goes to their families. Villages, towns, farmland, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by others, but the immense damage must still be painstakingly removed.
When addressing damage of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the European Union's member states.
Following the flood disaster of nineteen seventy-nine, Poland and, this time, other Central European states have again been affected by a flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and floods are an inherent characteristic of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, in awareness of the fact that these natural events can always occur, the correct preventative measures are
whether damage was caused by such natural events and whether, for example, the issues of sustainable disaster prevention received due consideration in landscape planning.
When assistance is provided, it should initially benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster in securing their livelihoods.

Then, however, preventative measures against damage from natural disasters should also be coordinated at the European level by the member states, particularly in international cooperation, as natural disasters do not respect state borders.

That jointly implemented preventative measures can offer protection is demonstrated by the flood protection measures along the Oder River, which have been jointly developed there to date by Polish and German authorities.
But we are not at the end yet.
We do not, however, require European civil protection.
The protection of a country from disasters should be primarily the responsibility of a country’s government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

However, the coordination of aid in the event of damage or incidents should also benefit from efficient European coordination, and organizations that provide voluntary, rapid, and low-bureaucratic assistance should not be left to bear their costs.

Mr. President, first and foremost, a heartfelt thank you to Mathieu Grosch for this profound report and the considerable effort he put into it.

That Europe exists without dividing borders is not experienceable without a functioning transportation system, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed, not even conceivable, without a high-performance transportation system, without high-performance, future-proof transportation systems on land, water, and in the air.
In particular, when it comes to environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more cooperation and less national self-interest.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transport must address the societal challenges in environmental protection and economics.

to burden the Cohesion Fund unilaterally and to relieve the Member States, which are particularly challenged, to an excessive degree in ensuring a sustainable future for transport.

Madam President, my esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen. We have a common internal market, but fragmented oversight.
It is self-evident that this cannot work.
We need strong central European structures that utilize the expertise and detailed knowledge of member states and institutions, but also possess the authority to intervene in emergencies.
I believe that the citizen, given the enormous tax burden they have been subjected to as a result of this crisis, expects prompt, swift, and well-reasoned decisions to be made here.
Citizens are largely unconcerned when power plays are enacted at the national level, where the sole question is Who decides?
What the citizen wants is for effective decisions to be made, for problems to be solved.

It is objectively the case that in emergency situations, when it comes to measures, these must be regulated and decided centrally at the European level if the coordination between Member States is insufficient and not functioning.
That aligns with the decisions of the G20, the G8, and the heads of state and government—unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The council moves in a small, compartmentalized manner.
That is not an acceptable policy for the citizens.
We expect the Council to take action.

My Lords Commissioners, dear colleagues,

One sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now with discussions and debates, with many meetings in the trilogue, where I could certainly have envisioned spending my time in a more pleasant way.
And we stand, over a year after the European elections, where we proclaimed on the streets and squares how we intended to tame the financial markets, facing a very meager to non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
Member States still maintain that they are able to enforce rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
That precisely did not work; he did not trigger the financial crisis with a contribution either, but did contribute to the fact that it also affected Europe.

Therefore, the question arises for me, at what point this realization, frequently articulated in Sunday speeches, will be translated into political action—where it suddenly concerns protecting stock exchange locations, where it concerns protecting banking structures, and no longer protecting citizens.

We, as the European Parliament, have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, for they bear joint responsibility for implementing sound regulatory oversight for citizens, ensuring that each individual’s savings remain permanently secure.

Naturally, gentlemen commissioners, I do wish that the Commission will now genuinely do everything possible to ensure that we reach a good outcome as quickly as possible in the interest of the people of Europe.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. We stand in this European Parliament with the responsibility for the robust regulation of financial markets.
All of what we proposed has been significantly diluted in the trilogues.
The government and cabinet do not seek extensive intervention powers.
Giegold is correct to describe what is currently happening as parochial thinking.
Not poor regulation, but rather to construct the system with somewhat fewer malfunctions appears to be the intention.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exert genuine control over financial markets.
From this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, inadequate consequences are drawn, thereby preparing the next crisis.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not withstand the next shocks, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
They expect this predatory financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervision and a common rule for all."
Member states and who advocates for stricter capital regulations, then that is an appeal to this Parliament to truly establish these rules.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to press the Council to now urgently implement effective regulation. This would be only the first step toward establishing the status quo.
Let concrete actions follow those bold promises at last. My faction stands for robust European regulation.
Anything short of regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a united EU, and to democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Poor timing for this statement.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it would have been the last time at this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we’re no longer allowed to watch, and then they probably won’t win after all.

But regarding the topic, Commissioner, you are giving the correct signal, Commissioner President. We will finalize today or tomorrow, to be precise, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
Not only is the controversy to blame for this, but also an intervening European election and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to us having to adjust certain matters.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise, one which is certainly worth affirming, even if one might perhaps do so with a clenched fist in one’s pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
That concerns the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
The objective here is to ensure that the best available technology in Europe is more effectively implemented.
I believe that we have found an exception clause in the current compromise that gives the EU Commission, Mr. Potocznik, and this is quite clear and directly addressed to you, the instrument in which

in the coming years to pay even more attention than previously to ensuring that the approximately fifty-two industrial facilities concerned in Europe ultimately utilize best available techniques more effectively than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address and reflect on one point here, because I simply cannot understand it.
I have often been told that the use of best available technology is too expensive, and that it thereby jeopardizes the competitiveness of European industry, especially during a crisis.
I do not readily recall my past, but I am from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to having missed, over decades, the investment in the final hours of technology.

I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is called upon for reasons of its own existence to invest in the latest state of the technology, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, incidentally, also reduces pollutant emissions.
I believe we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the directive—and this is something of a concentrated punch, as I mentioned—concerns large combustion plants.

We are discussing once again – we already addressed this in the previous directive – regarding renewed exemptions until the year 2020, in some cases until 2023, for large combustion plants that do not need to meet environmental requirements, particularly emission limits for air pollutants.
I am addressing this to the council, perhaps also a little to all of us, that we must very carefully consider how sensible it actually is that we regularly

Ambitious environmental goals are welcomed and discussed here, and are indeed welcome, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to codifying them into concrete legislation, a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then, member states suddenly realize what it costs, which bills must be paid, and those who have made preliminary commitments are usually penalized as a result.
There is, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and which, at the end, will be left standing in the rain.
I will reiterate here, both concerning industrial facilities and large-scale combustion plants, we are essentially discussing coal-fired power plants – we are not talking about science fiction.
We are not discussing things that are not available, but rather the state of the art.
Best available techniques – that which is available on the market under competitive and cost-related aspects – can be integrated into these facilities. Against this background, we conclude
Today, we are voting against a legislative package that I believe is superior to what is currently in effect, and for that reason, I encourage us all to approve it.

I would also like to thank my colleagues, some of whom have been intensely involved over the past two years, for their support, for their contributions, and above all, for the fact that nearly all important factions have co-signed this compromise.
Mr. President. Three interesting things have happened while we have been debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become the World Cup champion.
A good omen, I think.
Whether that will prove to be the case remains to be seen.
I simply do not wish to express any preferences at this time.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Thank you very much. That doesn’t happen every day either.
It is worth noting that.
Thirdly, the world is still in order—even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aykut has also left again.
Heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I wanted to raise two aspects regarding the debate I have just been following.
Firstly, I understand all the worries and hardships of my Eastern European friends only too well.
I, as someone from East Germany, am also, in a sense, half Eastern European.
I understand that not every environmental policy measure implemented in Western European countries in recent decades can be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be something one can afford.
Yes, that is correct.

But I believe that even taking this sentence into account, it is worthwhile to agree to this compromise, because it does justice to the diverse starting situations in which many Member States find themselves.
Secondly, the argument that employing best available techniques endangers competitiveness, particularly in comparison to China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must grapple with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are, without a doubt, cheaper than they are here.
We will only pass this test, however, if we employ the best available technology in as many industries as possible.
Whoever fails to do so loses competitiveness.
No one demands, not even this law, that an industrial operation be shut down tomorrow.
No one demands a jump from zero to one hundred to achieve any pollutant limit within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods, but to claim that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is incorrect.

I believe that with this directive, we have not only set an environmental policy course, but also an industrial policy one, for which it is worthwhile to work in the coming years. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by thanking my colleagues from the other groups in the preparation of my report on Kosovo, and also Ms. Eva Maar, who has done very valuable work here at the Secretariat.

And to you, Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also, as you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo, even to spend a night there, and thereby make it clear to the population that you stand for that population as well.
You delivered a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe that was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely its support for independent Kosovo on its path to the European Union.
We are currently facing a situation where Kosovo, and particularly the citizens of all ethnic groups within Kosovo, are once again at a critical juncture.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will deliver its opinion on the situation regarding the declaration of independence from just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion will be an opportunity, something like an open window, as it is called in English, to place regional cooperation on a new footing, but respecting national sovereignty.

emanating from Kosovo, to make clear that the shared future for all states in the region – for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others – lies within the European Union, and that on the path towards that goal, the problems that still exist must be resolved.
It is also the text of a resolution that makes clear the future of Kosovo lies within the European Union.

I am pleased that we have a majority that also urges the five member states that have not yet recognized [Kosovo/the entity] to do so soon, and that the Commission is once again urged to initiate visa liberalization as soon as possible.

For the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have that future.
I believe that is the task.
I hope to find a large majority for it tomorrow in the plenary session.

I have also submitted a new motion that emphasizes strong regret over the outbreaks of violence of the past few days and expresses great hope for swift and independent clarification, without allowing it to serve as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks.

Madam President, High Representative, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

The recent events in Kyrgyzstan—the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who abandoned their homes and tried to flee the violence—all of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
Simultaneously, these events in Kyrgyzstan also cast a spotlight on the situation in Central Asia, which should not leave us untouched here in the European Parliament.
On the contrary, we should devote our entire attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but consider all states equally within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which freed themselves from former tsarist and later Soviet rule less than twenty years ago, bear a heavy legacy.
The borders drawn arbitrarily by Stalin, without regard for the traditional homelands of the peoples living there, evidently complicate coexistence both within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions as exemplified in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands in
Labor migration forces and, as now acknowledged in Kyrgyzstan, conflict resolution through the use of violence cast a shadow of uncertainty over the future trajectory of these states.
Here, the European Union must not merely stand by.

If we do not wish to lead these states down paths of fundamentalist structures, if we do not wish to leave people there at the mercy of enduringly dictatorial regimes, it requires our full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material assistance, we need contact with these states, active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance, in satisfying Kyrgyzstan and on the path to stable political conditions, let us give her the opportunity for debate today and a vote tomorrow.

May standing resolutions also be followed by actions, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we will not abandon them on their path to the future, nor leave them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of these countries for us Europeans are high; we should not disappoint them. Thank you very much.
The report is correct for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will continue to cause us significant concern.
The second point is that the European ambassador will manage commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the safeguards for these risks remain entirely unclear.
The third point concerns the role of this Parliament's rights in a Council regulation.
We are, in this process, effectively sharing decision-making power, yet we have permitted a Council regulation to preempt parliamentary rights.
Therefore, I would like to state, for the purposes of my dossier, that I do not consider myself bound by today’s resolutions regarding the rules of procedure.
The fourth point concerns how we actually treat each other within Parliament.
We approved a parliamentary reform in the last period, and procedures that we are now all disregarding, with the agreement of the Presidium and also with the agreement of the President.
Why are we undertaking a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when, when it matters, we already violate and do not adhere to them?

For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report.
Sincerely.
Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
That is entirely incomparable to it.
Cloning is animal cruelty. Many colleagues have already stated this here.
I also presented this during the discussion before the summer break. Only a fraction of animal clones is actually viable.
And many, very, very many, die from those who survive, very early and in a very agonizing manner.
You are suffering from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have immune deficiencies, they are prone to illness.
That means pain and suffering and precisely that agonizing death.
How can we possibly be responsible for that?
We are committed to animal welfare and wish to support such technology.
No, that is not what we want, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
That is only consistent.

Yes, we know that products from cloned animals or their offspring are unlikely to be harmful to health, and I personally believe that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. But there is, in fact, no shortage of conventionally produced meat.
Why should we engage in cloning at all?
It is quite unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. The population simply does not want it.
The population does not want these products, we don’t need them ourselves either. There is no argument for cloned meat within the European Union.
Therefore, we want to establish a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and also for their offspring.
I want a ban on the cloning of cloned products within the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Naturally, this must also apply to imports.
I want to be certain that I am not surreptitiously served cloned meat, because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
I do not believe that all meat can be traced.
With beef, it may be possible.
However, with pork, due to the quantities produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether an animal was, at some point, a clone in its lineage.
Fundamentally, I believe it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said that we must also address ethical questions, and we are also responsible for ethical questions.
Naturally, the question of animal welfare arises, but it is also another question.
Experience shows. I am an animal producer; I studied it. Experience shows that all reproductive techniques, once they truly functioned in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
So, today we must ask ourselves: will and can we, in the not-too-distant future, accept cloning technology—and will and can we accept it even in the case of humans?
I do not want that, and I cannot do that either.
Even if a spare part clone could perhaps one day donate a life-sustaining organ to me, a clone of myself, then I would not want that.
I do not believe that is an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would be possible within not too distant a future, if we were to permit cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the entire EU.
I have no fear of the WTO.
We can enforce that.
We do not need to emulate everything the USA demonstrates, despite all trans-Atlantic friendship.

Mr. President. Thank you very much, colleagues. It is no coincidence that we find it so difficult to reach an agreement here in this case, because two irreconcilable subjects are being mixed together.
We would likely have been able to come to an agreement regarding trademark protection had we focused on it.
But the conflation with the substance of the Internet is also factually incorrect, because it requires new, different strategies here than in material law.
That cannot be easily transferred.
Furthermore, one must be clear that we pay for every prosecution online with infringements of civil rights, because one cannot see or ascertain this on one's own.

The third is really clear to me.
If I already subject cultural enjoyment on the web to the threat of penalties, so that I am practically always standing with one foot in the world
If I am in prison, then I will not be able to take advantage of the opportunities that the internet also offers for art, culture, and creativity.
Therefore, my appeal: let us continue discussing it.
Erik.
Mr. President. Property, whether intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of a market economy.
Therefore, I believe it is important that we consider how to resolve this matter together in a manner agreeable to all.
We absolutely need a transformation.
It must become easier for consumers, for the self-employed, and for small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain corresponding licenses here.
Precisely the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need, above all, the original language as well, so that it is available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible for licenses granted for a language to be valid throughout Europe and therefore utilized by all citizens.
We require interoperability and technical neutrality in order to utilize this intellectual property accordingly.
And we need, above all, sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament is already keen to discuss this matter, and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and assert that it will not respond to our questions or to our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council, in this context, whether it does or does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not a purely technical alteration, but signifies more tasks, means fulfilling more responsibilities, and consequently addressing related financial matters.
Furthermore, the Council adopted resolutions that will lead to new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the council desires this and if the council wishes that no further funds should be expended, then the council must also state precisely where it wishes to make savings, how it wishes to make savings, where it wishes to reallocate funds exactly, and not merely offer generalities.

to propose percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences lie, especially since our possibilities for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The additional tasks you assigned us are, however, so challenging that they do not involve minor, incidental sums, but I mention alone the areas of financial stability of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
If the program needs to be utilized, then these are not insignificant sums that one could simply reallocate at will.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to questions of internal security, the same applies to major research questions, and the same also applies to questions when I address priority areas of the Parliament, namely in the field of youth education and research.
We are partially dealing with a lack of implementation, and partially also with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and worked through concretely, and not answered by silence on the part of the council.
Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues. I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we speak of mountains, islands, and sparsely populated regions, I gain the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European resolutions and objectives remains, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the responsibility of the Member States.

When I consider the European level, we have consistently paid particular attention to precisely these areas—mountainous regions, sparsely populated areas, islands—in Commission communications, all the way up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here, too, in Parliament, many resolutions were passed to support this region.
When I hear so many complaints here now that problems persist in those regions, the question arises for me: how have the member states dealt with the impulses that we sent from the European level?
And how did the regions themselves address this and utilize European funding opportunities?

Here, a new strategy is being demanded; and I already feel sympathy for the officials at DG Regio, who are tasked with incorporating the multitude of problems facing islands, mountainous regions, and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

Simultaneously, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies—Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and similar matters—to the point where we need a strategy for the strategies themselves, so that we can still maintain an overview.

Esteemed colleagues, joking aside. What it is really about – and this has also been mentioned today, for which I, Commissioner Hahn, am very grateful – is that we must fight to ensure that there is a cohesion policy and a regional policy at the European level even after 2013.
That is the focus of our work, and in that we should also convince our colleagues in parliament that this will be the case.
And as a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond the year two thousand thirteen, mountains, islands, and other regions will also find their place.
However, we should not become bogged down in individual draft resolutions on this topic, for which there is currently no occasion. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. First and foremost, my thanks to the colleagues who have worked so intensely on this project, particularly Mr. Vidal Quadras.
This is the proof that European policy is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that provide further assistance.
We have experienced this supply security situation on multiple occasions.
The problem of supply security has thus become clearer and more distinct.
We were compelled to act, and we have acted.

We have found solutions that were not simple, solutions that also mean new instruments, and what I find particularly interesting about this is not just creating infrastructure standards in Europe, not just establishing common rules for prevention and emergency plans, not just the certainty, as the Commissioner rightly
has demonstrated, that we can offer people thirty days of security in the future, but has also shown that we are able to explore compromises, compromises that can then lead to actionable solutions.

We have been laboriously navigating this path, but it is now evident that both the role and responsibility of companies—those who build the grids, who are responsible for the grids—and the agility of politics, which states that we will not force things that ultimately prove uneconomical and imprudent—are central.

no longer sensible. For example, flexibility regarding backflows in necessary backflows, but not to say across everything and always and at any price, but also the necessity or the possibility of being able to assess individual cases, just as strengthening cooperation at the regional level.

Equally important is the note that Member States must also assume their responsibilities, but when solutions cannot be found there, the Commission then receives an additional task—the Commission, which is strengthened, but does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible, or has the final say.
Also, flexibility—solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but last but not least, ensure that solutions exist, and that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr. President, my dear colleagues, my highly esteemed Commissioners. I need not emphasize how important cohesion and regional policy are for the social fabric and integration within Europe.
However, I also believe that the regional and cohesion policies of the future must increasingly focus on cities.
For cities are an important engine in Europe’s development.
At the same time, however, they are currently experiencing particularly acute ecological, economic, and social problems.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn: What possibilities do you see for highlighting the urban dimensions?

Specifically, Commissioner, you recently suggested at an event here at our institution that you could envision a certain percentage being reserved from the regional funds, precisely to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
And if so, what percentage could this potentially be?

Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here, as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, that can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe were to create one additional job, we would have no unemployment in Europe anymore.
Therefore, we should consider how we can empower small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular, to onboard new employees and, accordingly, become actively engaged in international export markets.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, just as infrastructure in the transport sector is.
Here, the Commission faces significant tasks, particularly restructuring the East-West connection, for example, Paris-Budapest, or the North-South route.
Here, additional jobs can be created, which we currently urgently need in Europe.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. Undeniably, we have made progress in gender equality in recent years. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are forced into low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, employment subject to social security contributions has frequently been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure work relationships.
There, particularly women.
European employment trends from two thousand to two thousand ten encompass sixty new, precarious, and atypical employment relationships, predominantly affecting two-thirds of them women.
Frequently, women are denied democratic participation due to their part-time employment or precarious employment in businesses.
Women are, however, significantly more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
You still earn twenty-five less than men on average.

We have engaged extensively with this topic in the Employment Committee and developed good proposals regarding the employment of women, encompassing their inclusion irrespective of their employment status.
social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems with independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of decent work.
All of this has essentially been adopted from the report on Precarious Employment of Women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the results of this work and requests approval for the submitted report. Thank you.
Madam Chair, Mr. President, landmines will likely continue to pose a significant problem for the foreseeable future.
Do you believe it is possible to initiate one’s own research programs for the detection of landmines?
That is not merely a European problem; it is a global problem.
