Colleagues,

In the transatlantic dialogue, there is much that unites us on both sides, namely fundamental values and basic rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also differences, namely in the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Especially when it comes to security issues, this contradiction becomes strikingly clear time and again.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings, something we have known for a long time.
Therefore, the framework agreement, should we succeed in securing a very good one, will be a significant step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar fundamentals but very different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I greatly desire that it becomes a topic and that it is discussed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to undermine its own promises and commitments.
For investment fund managers, a degree of transparency and regulation is emerging in this opaque jungle of hedge funds and alternative investment funds for the first time.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It remains possible to access the common market with unregulated products within the framework of passive distribution.
Fundamentally, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and to achieve a unified regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what the Parliament desired, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It remains the responsibility of national regulations alone to limit the extent of a fund’s indebtedness, and this means that the consequences of the crisis are not being addressed here.
This will result in a national race to the bottom in regulation.
What remains crucial for us is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is also not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are Private Equity Investments that are sensible for companies.
But the rules now being implemented are, unfortunately, far from sufficient.
Also ineffective are the information rights of employees, whom they rightly expect, as is the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of exploitation.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this in this case vis-à-vis the voters.

Unfortunately, the responsibility for this does not lie with Parliament; it lies particularly with intensive lobbying efforts by the corresponding industry, successfully undertaken, especially in the UK.

Government, within the French government, but I must unfortunately say also partially within the German one, and we had here in Parliament representation of these lobbyists primarily in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree with this proposal, as it would set a precedent for the Parliament’s failure to enforce effective regulations.
It is not possible for us to stand before our voters with heads held high and say that we have successfully regulated this shadow realm.
We hope that we will be able to make further progress when revising the guideline.
Many thanks once again, and especially for the collaboration here with colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you very much. Also, my sincere thanks initially to my colleague Balz for the collaboration.
I can only emphasize this; even with differing positions, it has been a positive collaboration.
Many believed—and I want to reiterate this point here—that the Eurozone crisis was over.
Your country demonstrates that this was not the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily surrender itself to the financial markets.
The member states of the EU must continue to hawk their sovereign bonds on the marketplace of financial markets and acquire the trust of speculators through austerity.
Over the weekend, we once again had to observe where that leads.

This time, it was not the Greeks, supposedly prone to fraud, but model student Ireland who was driven into the European rescue funds to save its banking system, which had long been considered exemplary, exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already eyeing Portugal's capitalization, as its interest rates continue to rise.
The ECB bears a share of responsibility for this drama.
She failed to provide, and continued to fail to provide, a civilized alternative to the state casino through the issuance of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB watches impassively as the other half continues to sink further into poverty and insecurity.
The austerity measures imposed on entire national economies may suit the tastes of European funds and banking crises, but they have neither helped Ireland nor the monetary union nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, aren’t you listening to Mrs. Merkel’s simple finance ABCs?
Secondly, if you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not let European government bonds be left hanging.
Introduce Euro Bonds before the next speculation victim falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. Considering how we discussed this Commission proposal in the previous legislative term – from total rejection to expressions of great enthusiasm about what was coming our way – I must say I am delighted with what is now before us.
And great thanks are due to the rapporteur and their co-rapporteurs for having formed a coherent opinion from this wide spectrum of viewpoints.
I believe the magic word for that lies in a patient-centered approach.
One has not, therefore, considered the various side effects, but has instead asked: What does the patient need?
I believe it is correct that we have agreed that the patient can obtain information through various channels and not just one.
However, I would like to emphasize that the physician will continue to be the patient’s primary confidant and will also certainly exert influence in critical matters.
We guarantee this, because we have, in fact, prohibited advertising for it and the information the patient receives has been reviewed and approved by an authority.
This provides the information with initial scientific substantiation, and thereby the patient can also confidently handle it.
Naturally, it is correct that not everyone can undertake this investigation now.
Regarding the internet. We have various ways for that, and I believe it is so widely used that we don’t need to worry about it.
I only hope that the council now finally has the courage to address this topic.
It is very important; it must be acted upon swiftly.
The patients expect that.
And I believe we have then accomplished a good work. Many thanks.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Coal is a part of the energy supply; that is indisputable.
It is also undeniable that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization may not be the appropriate path.
The question now is whether the appointment with two fourteen or two eighteen is the correct one.
My colleague Rabke has presented a great many insightful arguments that I need not repeat.

My request to the Commission is essentially only this: There is evidently a large majority in Parliament, in all the committees involved, in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that we establish the necessary flexibility in the matter of the timing, which is essential to ensure the possibility for Member States to implement it, and that the burdens on people, on jobs, and on economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been raised – incidentally, also contrary to the Commission’s impact assessment, which initially seemed to favor two eighteen – was that climate policy considerations might play a role here.
I want to emphasize this point once again: It makes no difference to the question of climate whether one burns foreign coal or one's own coal.

My request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year period, should it arise in Parliament and if a similar new line of argument emerges in the Council, could not also cause the Commission to become somewhat flexible.
I understood the comment just now to mean that the commission is considering this, and I thank you for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner. If one must draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, then it is that the European Union must speak with a single voice at such conferences in the future.

We may, at various points, have differing opinions on this, but if we, as Europeans, already speak with disparate voices, then our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, then others will not follow us.
Why should you?
Therefore, it is correct that the figures we decided upon in the final year of two thousand two under Chancellor Merkel must, in essence, remain valid and form the foundations of these negotiations.

I share your view that the ambitious two-degree target should not be seriously questioned in favor of a significantly lower figure, as this would render achieving those targets extraordinarily difficult and would alienate the public.
I am greatly concerned that we are jeopardizing our intellectual property.
Also, our industry invests both capital and manpower in developing things.
If we were to go there now and loosen the fence around this intellectual property, leaving the holes as they are at present, then the valuable parts—namely, our property—would simply walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a point in investing in it, and therefore intellectual property must not be diluted.
Regarding commitments, I am also inclined to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we will do precisely the opposite of what we intend, namely, you will distance yourselves from us.
Being believable in Cancun is also an important point.
The major decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, then there will be nothing with the harvest.
Let us focus on the accomplished academic.
Mr. President. During the debate on the European Council this morning, an incident occurred to which I no longer wish to respond, as I was the target of an insult.
However, I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be offended and where I do not perceive something as an insult, because to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of seriousness.
I would, however, like to express my sincere gratitude for the countless expressions of solidarity I have received here in this building since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our collective, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which is shared by the overwhelming majority of this House.
For this, my sincere thanks.

Dear Commissioner, Dear Minister, Dear Mr. Gosses, and esteemed colleagues and shadow rapporteurs. First and foremost, I am pleased that we have now made this step possible, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is being placed under European direct supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe within a single market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.

I would like to allow myself one further remark, dear Mr. Barnier. Currently, the selection processes for the new authorities are underway, and the new authorities are only as good as their personnel.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, the focus will genuinely be on expertise, on independence from the financial industry they are meant to control, and on a clear commitment to the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that supersede these important criteria.
Furthermore, much remains to be done in the field of rating agencies.

We still lack proper transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings in the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We have significant conflicts of interest, we have a clear market dominance by three major providers, and we bear no liability for negligently prepared ratings.
Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are eager to see the results.
I believe that civil society, too, should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I look forward to receiving your proposal.
Let us be as courageous as we have been thus far, and let us together legislate next year to truly resolve the problems that still exist in the credit rating market – in a genuinely European manner.
That is what we owe to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues. The damage that rating agencies can inflict has been demonstrated in recent months since the beginning of this year.
Therefore, there is an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I also welcome the directive insofar as I welcome the fact that the ESMA would be entrusted with the supervision and registration of rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive proposals failed to make it through the negotiations regarding the report.
I would like to reiterate that here.
The appointment of ESMA therefore remains the only genuine and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public data base for the creation of ratings have fallen by the wayside, and there is no mention of the establishment of a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.

The Commission had also continued to propose funding for independent ratings in order to overcome detrimental issuer instructions for the assessment of financial products, but nothing of that has remained either.
I hope that these aspects will be considered in the remaining reports on this topic, which Jean Paul Groset and also you, Mr. Barnier, have mentioned. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. First of all, my thanks to those who worked on this report, in particular to Colleague Benson.
I would like to draw attention to two points and perhaps provoke a little thought.
We agree that energy efficiency, the economical use of energy, is the simplest and most reasonable solution.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to pose the question: What, actually, has it achieved that we repeatedly approached the people in Parliament with new and higher percentages?
Have we truly achieved more and accomplished more?
Or why, and in what areas, was energy used more sparingly?
I am learning that industry, which consumes a great deal of energy, handles energy more efficiently because it saves money that way and because it is advantageous for them.
I am learning that people will choose this option when they know that this device consumes more or less energy, when they see it and can decide for themselves that there is an advantage.
Perhaps the method is not correct in working with percentages, but rather correct in proceeding through incentives.
Second Question The Commissioner has just stated very impressively and clearly how complicated the mere description of the concept “What is that actually?” is.
How differently is this implemented in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the Member States also have very different situations—economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it then the correct approach to work with a number, with a binding number, or must something else not occur to us?

I believe we must, in energy policy, distance ourselves from the debates of the past, which, through simple figures, binding targets, and so-called miracle solutions, aim to achieve something. Because it is obvious that we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try, at some point, the other approach—the approach of differentiated, varied responses that acknowledge the different situations and sensitivities, but also achieves impact.
It depends on the effects, it does not depend on our state of being.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in all the committees for a long time.
Now, at the end, when the results were available, some people in this institution stirred.
Some are unfortunately not present for the debate now. It would have been very interesting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convent, the spirit of the Convent remains vividly clear to me.

who has consistently demanded, across many areas, that the European Parliament must acquire specific rights in order to maintain its credibility both within the institutions and vis-à-vis the citizens.
In that case, what the convent has given us was still not a gift.
It was an extremely difficult negotiation, particularly by the Belgian presidency vis-à-vis the Council, which made it possible to achieve some important progress.
I recall what my colleague Lehne already stated: it was precisely the question of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission has exceeded its competencies.
Of course, there are some arrangements that are not entirely ideal, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
She truly dedicated herself to ensuring something would happen, and to our reporter, who negotiated with heart and mind.
In 2013, I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a motion that my colleague Göran Färm submitted in the Committee on Budgets on behalf of our group.
We did not resubmit this amendment, but the Green Party faction has resubmitted the motion with forty signatures from Green parliamentarians.
We will abstain from this application.
I have also reached an understanding with my colleagues from the Green Party. We are absolutely of the same opinion on this matter.
However, since we have fundamentally stated that we, as a faction, will not be submitting any new amendment proposals now, we will abstain.

I would, however, like to state explicitly that we support this point, the Financial Transaction Tax, and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
It is important that we do not use national tax systems to counteract the internal market.
Especially with cross-border services, this is particularly important. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price ceilings were introduced as a crisis management measure.
That is unacceptable, particularly the financial insurance and commercial sectors, but energy is also heavily affected here.
I hope that this will not also be applied in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these arrangements, as they fundamentally contravene the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of existing legal regulations.
Similarly, there are scarcely any well-developed calculations and analyses for the new proposals.
I must state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The contemplation of reality unfortunately also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is being claimed, or even deliberately abused, for entirely different reasons.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of the twenty-seven member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get the opportunity, through our asylum law, to profit to the tune of billions from the fate of people.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and thorough manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the assurance of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, corresponding obligations are foreseen by the Commission in the new drafts.
I consider many of these points to be correct, such as interpretation, proper medical care, and consideration of particular protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities in the Member States have far too few opportunities to counter abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited proceedings and border procedures should not be unduly restricted.

When an applicant significantly violates their duty of cooperation, there are few possibilities for sanctions, quite the contrary. If they abscond illegally, the Member State should no longer be able to terminate their proceedings negatively; should they reappear, a broader range of procedural options should be available to them.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an expedited procedure should be possible following the second successive application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even pro bono legal advice in the form of an attorney currently represents a significant cost increase for the states, according to the Commission's draft wording.
I simply request that the Commission reconsider the consequences of its proposals for practical reality, the financial implications, and the challenges for the administrations of the Member States.
We want to maintain a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, must not place particularly burdened member states in utterly impossible situations.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor once again briefly.
I have a considerable request of you, Commissioner Fühle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to inaccurate cost estimates.
We are not currently seeing declining figures in the asylum seeker area, but rather a significantly increasing number.
That has to do with visa facilitations, for example, with Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in attempts to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from false assumptions—namely that challenging the initial proceedings in a higher, more qualified form would save costs in subsequent instances—one automatically assumes, so to speak, that all member states have a deficient initial proceeding.
That is not the case.
When standards are raised overall, it inevitably leads to cost increases.
An increase in quality standards for all involved, as well as the complication of procedures, leads to higher costs in practical reality. I am happy to discuss this.
Therefore, I earnestly request once again that the concerns of the federal states be taken seriously, as the practical reports from the states are partially available and being presented.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen. This report certifies a successful competition policy for the Commission.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and a widening gap between the rich and the poor.
Unfettered competition still ranks above the social needs of people in the European Union.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail but are also incapable of establishing social justice permanently.
A few procedures regarding market distortion and price fixing do not resolve this problem.
A fair and simultaneously social internal market functions only with strong and equitable regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for example, not acceptable to subject an increasing number of public service institutions to private sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission’s future competition policy.
Far stronger consumer protection, the exclusion of public utilities from competition rules, and the control of cartels – all of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for secured social progress would be necessary, one that stands at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
It is a truly significant moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time today in the European Parliament.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a fourteen-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote to him in 1943 before his deportation from a German children’s home to Auschwitz.
He wrote, "I have found my parents again."
We are in transit to the concentration camp.
I have mustered my inner resolve to such an extent that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for all you have done for me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven.

Yours,
Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like five hundred other Roma and Sinti. Although Roma and Sinti, alongside Jews, were among the first victims of industrialized mass murder, the full truth about it remains unspoken today, sixty-six years later.
And also the complicity of the mainstream society is often obscured.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be prosecuted as a crime against humanity and acknowledged, so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put an end to racist hostility and acts of violence, such as those that occurred in Hungary last year, and do so with civic courage.
Freedom and equality and solidarity are not privileges of the individual, but the rights of all, for human and civil rights are indivisible.

Distinguished ladies and gentlemen, colleagues,

From my perspective, it is now a matter of truly exploring the possibilities of the law in the
We have doubts as to whether these possibilities have truly been exhausted institutionally.
We observe deficiencies in the process. As parliament, we have not received the candidate list in advance, but only the finalized result to date.
It would be straightforward to send it to the Executive Directors now.

We clearly have a deficit in gender equality regarding the appointment of positions, and we have doubts, based on certain occurrences within the process, that the member states are truly appointing individuals to these institutions in the European interest.
This and the further points in our letter justify posing a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it naturally concerns the suitability of the individual persons, and in that case, each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

During the hearings, we observed that one of the candidates questioned whether it was a European institution, instead referring to a network of supervisory authorities and, even when asked, was not prepared to correct this.
In response to the question of whether you are prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we received no clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Mr. President. We, as the Social Democratic parliamentary group, have the same motion to submit.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and to this Assembly that we formulate it somewhat more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather substantial influx.

And Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean, is undoubtedly overwhelmed in attempting to manage the current problem alone. And Italy certainly will not be the only country confronted with the mass influx of refugees.
We can reasonably assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be that we frame the title of the statement very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission regarding immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in managing the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is also achieved in the field of coach transport, for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.
achieved, secondly ensuring a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly taking account of the fact that the sector is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Thus, the extreme demands that would have rendered bus transport virtually impossible due to excessive requirements are off the table, as are demands that would have excluded the majority of member states from the scope of the regulation entirely.
Bus services that benefit the public at large must also offer a high quality of service to people with disabilities and those with limited mobility.
You should be entitled to assistance; in the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President. I would like to congratulate everyone, particularly the colleague Mr. Kancian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy development of a compromise in this challenging dossier.
There were successes, which have already been listed, but also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties, which have already been presented.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have addressed passenger rights for all modes of transportation.
The next necessary step is to establish a common, coherent, and efficient framework for all passenger rights.
Just and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
To maintain credibility, therefore, the coherence of rights for the various modes of transport must absolutely be respected.
It is unavoidable that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of air passengers than, for example, to those of train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework program not to consider the lowest and weakest standards, but to ensure that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues. We are in a major economic crisis, something we have been discussing for months – and that is indeed the case. However, we generally speak in headlines and then proceed here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it stems from the fact that we, even in parliament, do not behave with sufficient specificity and honesty, but rather it is this kind of headline politics that prevails.
What does one actually do to advance growth and stability?
Are we ourselves also contributing to handling finances more properly and judiciously?
Have we truly conducted a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day as to where more money can be spent?

If we lack the capacity to concentrate financial resources on future projects—that is to say, conflict and debate and decision-making—then it is pointless to speak of innovation and research, but not provide the means to support them.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also enact policies that stimulate it, and not spend from morning till night contemplating how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to pass resolutions, demanding new resolutions even today, which disrupt economic developments.
Does anyone truly believe that citing merely one example of binding energy efficiency targets contributes to driving economic progress?
Do you genuinely believe that our decisions, frequently made in the context of energy, have stimulated the economy?
Or were you disruptive?
I would like us to be a bit more honest about this and then also make fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move things forward.
That is more strenuous, more laborious, and will also mean disagreement, but that is the point of democracy.
Mr. President. Colleagues. The demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years, opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax.
Yet, just five years ago, few would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda in the European Parliament alongside a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that’s a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments proposed by Anni Podimata in her report, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has thus far focused solely on reducing expenditures.
The reduction of public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poor—that is, those dependent on the welfare state.
The revenue side of public authorities has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment lever one can turn to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, those primarily responsible for the public debt crisis can also be adequately involved in the reduction of public debt through revenue-generating measures.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public sector debt is primarily a consequence of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of private banks’ debts and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis, therefore, does not lie solely with the states.
It is therefore not only logical but also politically necessary to call the financial sector to account.
The financial transaction tax would finally involve this sector, a principal cause of public debt, in the reduction of that debt.
This represents a significant political signal emanating from this report, should it be adopted as presented.
But we also consider Euro Bonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to debt reduction than all sanctions or well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, as these surplus countries simultaneously also profit from their exports to deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
However, whoever desires a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to remain united in the future, must, in principle, at least agree to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that it will now, at long last, present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been requested for over a year.
Mr. President, the rescue shields should protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they burden citizens with brutal austerity programs while leaving those responsible unscathed. Furthermore, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Hahn, it is absurd and brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argumentation here, as it was evidently not intended to be socio-political in nature.
This position is entirely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the responsibility of the EU; this policy of the Commission stands in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for a race to the bottom in wages and social dumping.
There it reads about rigidity of wages, which are to be reduced.
That is to say, wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, the blind are talking about color—those who formulate such statements have absolutely no understanding of collective bargaining agreements.
They interfere with wage bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to state this clearly: This Parliament is required to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent further dismantling of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

Therefore, I am asking again: If Mr. Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain facilities connected to the grid will not survive our stress tests, I interpret that as you having knowledge that these facilities are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why don't you intervene today already?
In my view, that is a real danger.
Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to address this topic with soundbites.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union itself...
must finally fulfill its commitments regarding development aid and that it cannot, in any way, be tolerated that member states increasingly evade this commitment.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still hunger every day and that the majority of them live in LDCs, that is, in the poorest countries of the world.

It is unacceptable that a significant portion of our development aid does not go towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but rather that this proportion has rapidly declined in recent years, with a billion people suffering from hunger.
And then to talk about that. We hope that LDCs become more shock-resistant; I'm finding that increasingly cynical.
I urge you to address the problems specifically and clearly and to assume concrete commitments in order to genuinely assist the LDCs.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law, the awarding of public contracts, is a key component.

Mr. Barnier, if you state that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That belongs to the fundamental rules that you, as you say, do not intend to question yourself.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it will be necessary in the future when awarding public contracts to ensure that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is effectively prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
I explicitly state that social fundamental rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want a permanent conflict with the people who turn away from this Europe, in which they do not see their vital interests safeguarded.

Dear Madam President, dear Commissioner Kruse,

Radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration of societal aspects as a whole.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program assumes a particularly significant role.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To this end, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized across all bandwidth segments to generate maximum efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year, as it also stipulated that radio frequency management for the EU and its member states must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be considered particularly when harmonizing frequency usage within the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I has proceeded at very different speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the UAF band, particularly below eight hundred megahertz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The interference issues and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities during technical upgrades, for example in the area of radio microphones, have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When allocating frequency bands, the various interests must be responsibly balanced against one another.

The widespread provision of mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a fundamental demand in the interest of European citizens. Simultaneously, however, continued development in the areas of public and private broadcasting must also be considered as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course correctly for Europe’s technical development in the area of digital information technology and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn. I would first like to say that, as you have described, the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone: the divide widens between countries that are recovering and those that are weaker.
and the costs of supporting the weaker countries continue to rise.

In this situation, I have several questions for you. As currency commissioner, I ask you: on day two, liabilities and receivables between the central banks within the ECB system had accumulated to over four hundred billion euros.
This is due to the fact that banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities, which are not provided for by the Eurosystem?
Then the major problem as to why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly structured.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present it?
And how do you, as Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as the Greens had predicted for some time, that the measures against Greece and Portugal would not take effect as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not better.
We continue to observe absolutely rising interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
while increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, particularly from the strong euro countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if one excludes recent fluctuations.

Beyond the bailout for these countries, beyond the assistance on the financing side, I wonder what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries receive relief macroeconomically – at the level of taxation, regarding external demand, and concerning the question of interest rates.
And you?
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries within the Eurozone.

And finally, in my view, the measures have affected the most vulnerable in countries like Greece, Portugal, and Spain, contravening the spirit of the EU Treaty, while the stronger, the wealthier, have not yet been called upon to bear a portion of the burdens.
What measures are you taking to ensure that those with wealth also contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President, Ms. Kinga Gönz is a member of my parliamentary group.
One can be opposed to Ferenc Joachani, one can be in favor of Ferenc Joachani.
One can reject Kinga Gönz as a politician or support her.
It is certainly open to each individual to freely and independently determine whether they are for or against a person's political conviction.
The debate we are conducting here is about the last dictatorship that exists in Europe.
And we lead them past one of the most brutal and bloodthirsty dictators Europe has ever known.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that an elected democratic member of my parliamentary group is being compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that the parliament must also reject this, particularly from a representative of a party that distinguishes itself by covering the Roma minority in Hungary with a hatred and persecution unparalleled in Europe.
If anyone here is not entitled to criticize Ms. Kinga Gönz, it is Ms. Mauer.

Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, and dear visitors,

The cultural diversity of Europe is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further expanded in the future.
To make this possible, we must confront the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the realm of culture and the creative industries.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but also a significant economic factor.
Approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector within the EU.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half times the total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the broader economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven as much by the content offered by the cultural sector as the technology itself has changed and advanced the nature and quality of that content.
We therefore need to create framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that will allow them to develop sustainably in light of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can fully develop.
Culture and the creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also focus on this area within the realms of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also within the offerings of lifelong learning.

However, we must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, and not only entrepreneurial competencies, but also a good level of media literacy in the area of new technologies.
We need frameworks within which cultural creators can secure their livelihoods.

Therefore, we will need to engage intensively with questions of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as the open access to information and content, in order to foster the advancement

to ensure that the creative and cultural industries continue to thrive in a digital environment and to preserve Europe’s cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic states, dear colleagues. Today, we commemorate in particular the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic states.
These expulsions belong to the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was, not least for this reason and not incorrectly, also named a century of expulsions.
And we all bow our heads today in remembrance of the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

And today's Russia should not interpret this as a political attack, but rather as support for the examination of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by periods of sunshine and shadow.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the previous century.
We reflect on the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular climax in the mid-century through the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
Expulsions following the Second World War also left deep wounds, as did those during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by displacement.
We must demand a serious engagement with the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications thereof.
And this includes clarifying responsibility and punishing the guilty, as far as that is still possible, as is currently the case with Mladic, for example.

But the decisive answer is European unity, particularly through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European integration process, which remains incomplete.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but particularly to the victims of the numerous expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, from East and West, have worked on it.
Let us consider, for example, the Danzig Declaration signed by the Polish President Wojciechowski and the German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even towards initial signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all such statements, for example, the suggestion that Arab migrants should be returned in boats across the Mediterranean. And we must resist when some seek to dismantle Europe’s achievements of openness and to usher in a new, restrictive nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence before all victims of displacement and deportation, but let us unanimously commit to continuing European unification as the only true guarantee against a
The politics that brought so much misfortune to the people of Europe, but also far beyond. Never to forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost their validity; they are best safeguarded in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary observer, to witness the referendum on South Sudan’s independence, and I was impressed by the strong support of the South Sudanese people in their desire to determine the future of their country themselves.
I also observed the great anticipation among the people, who viewed their country’s independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called internally displaced persons, driven by decades of conflict in the south to refugee camps in the north, set out for their former homeland in South Sudan.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the country's independence, desire above all to live in peace and to forge a path toward a happier future after all the decades of armed conflict in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July ninth, the new state of South Sudan is now scheduled to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are extremely unfavorable, and much has already been said about that here.
Seventy people live as normalizing livestock breeders, eighty are illiterate. The conflict over Abiyé is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and according to estimates by observers, more than people are said to have lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the violated are scarcely counted.
Sudan already belonged to the category of failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already beginning to resemble a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a significant obligation of Europe towards this region.
in view of the colonial past of those countries. Together with the UN and the African Union, a common European foreign policy is needed here, and it can prove itself here as well.
It is not only about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate firmly with those whose fate rests upon it—namely, the tribal leaders, heading the military groups—that they do not betray the hopes of their people within the country. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Mr. Bartolozzi for having made Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative for this request.
While the formerly Soviet states of Central Asia are now treated from various perspectives in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation found only scant resonance here.
Quite unjustly, it was Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, relatively early utilized its independence and embarked on a path towards the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, Mongolia adopted a democratic constitution, and several elections have since taken place, which, according to observers, overall proceeded in a democratic and correct manner – a development that is far from commonplace for states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting to combat corruption through legislation for several years and issued a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, a feat that even some large democratic states have yet to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this geographically large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, suffer from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
And so, a predominantly land-dwelling population, still largely living a nomadic existence, is pressing into the few towns that are not prepared infrastructurally for this influx.
The country’s natural resources are not being extracted in an environmentally sound manner.
Energy problems are making civilian and economic life more difficult.
Squeezed between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is threatened with becoming even more dependent on these states than previously.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia—and here I see the glass half full, not half empty, regarding the democratization of society—should be recognized, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only within the framework of aid programs, but also by ensuring the European Union has a direct presence in the Mongolian capital with its own
Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests will no longer be represented from Peking. One sentence, please.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. Interregional cooperation will increasingly gain in significance in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macroregional collaboration are exceedingly important for achieving the goals of 2020 in an increasingly integrated Europe.

Cross-border concepts and projects, such as those in the areas of infrastructure, corporate collaborations, research cooperation, labor market development, and vocational training, are a driving force for large parts of the European Union.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. After almost three years of intensive work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations, discussions,

Debates. Following arduous technical negotiations and political trilogues, the political package—the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council—on the future labeling of foodstuffs is now up for vote.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all; the European food industry is also to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and improved legislation are the goal.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is crucial to understand that the food sector in the European Union consists of over eighty percent SMEs.
Simultaneously, this labeling must be appropriate for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready meals.
That is why a mandatory labeling system using traffic light colors is also not possible, because this labeling simply does not suit basic foodstuffs.

Despite all difficulties, despite all political and ideological differences within the Parliament, despite all national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved is nonetheless impressive.
Allergens will be clearly identifiable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is specified.
There is an origin labeling requirement for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For further products, a consequence assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and milk products, i.e., products that consist of a principal ingredient, meat in processed
Imitations, etc., must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to form meat and fish composed of, or assembled from, small pieces.
Packaging must not create the impression that it contains something that is not actually present.
If a picture of fruit appears on a yogurt container, then fruit must also be present inside, and not merely coloring and flavorings.
Additionally, the mandatory indication of the most important nutrients is always given per hundred grams or hundred milliliters for the sake of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first deep-freezing for meat and fish, and many other details.
Above all, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have tasked the commission with establishing binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we are protecting crafts from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unfully packaged fresh products are required to provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information, which requires expensive analyses.

The Commission initially wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialties; it would have led to a European homogenized mass, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the serious consumer advocates are certainly satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully deliver shortly and which will break the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

And I would like to thank, in particular, the Hungarian presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected—nearly squaring the circle—the agreement on this regulation. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

In view of the current exceptional situation as a result of the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential matters.
Only in this way can we restore trust among our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report concerns the strategy for avoiding endless human suffering, resulting from approximately thirty-five deaths and over one.
five million instances of severe injuries as a result of traffic accidents, as well as to prevent the associated economic damage of one hundred and thirty billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to what would be mourned in the crash of two hundred and fifty fully occupied medium-sized commercial aircraft.
What wouldn’t we do to prevent that?
The costs resulting from accidents significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
Therefore, I am confident that it would serve us well to become sustainably active in this area.

Thanks to the constructive collaboration of all shadow rapporteurs as well as many colleagues, for the first time with this report we have succeeded in developing a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road safety.

He takes into account the content of the UN Charter for Road Safety from 2010 to 2020, as well as the content and objectives of road safety work by EU member states and broader circles of civil society.
It encompasses, firstly, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period until two thousand twenty and, with Vision Zero, for the period thereafter.

Therefore, the aim is to reduce the number of fatal accident victims by fifty, the number of child fatalities even by sixty, and the number of severely injured by forty by the year two thousand twenty.
That lies in the most fundamental interest of each individual among our people, but also in our national economy.
We recommend that Member States break down targets and methods to their territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is far from being solely the European Union.

In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regionally or locally responsible enterprises, and indeed each individual road user, within the scope of their duty to cooperate, have a responsibility to assume.
And thirdly, it includes how—that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures—the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to forgo guidelines, recommendations, or mandates.
Particular attention was paid to subsidiarity, meaning that responsibilities and accountabilities were clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, as they originate from the most diverse directorates-general, such as Transport, Economy, Consumer Protection, Environment, Communications, Research and Development, Internal Market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and, in some cases, contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the establishment of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This permanently avoids the establishment of an agency for road safety, but significantly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while ensuring a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields, areas of action, were identified.
It concerns human beings as traffic participants, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request your approval tomorrow.

must be given particular consideration, and this is also included, and I believe it is important and good that vulnerable road users are finally brought into focus, and I hope that these measures will ultimately and definitively be implemented.

under the condition that the industries in Europe, which are unduly burdened thereby, can experience relief, because otherwise they will not be able to withstand competition with other regions of the world.

Mr. President. I would first like to thank the representative of the Council for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have consistently heard in this debate that it concerns improving the situation for working women who are considering having a child.
In my opinion, the directive places too much emphasis on increasing maternity leave to twenty weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to twenty weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am very well aware that comprehensive concepts for offers and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines do not even remotely do justice to the diverse, and in some cases very good, offer and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that address the situation in member states and societies, and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful performances do not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we must first develop a solid and realistic foundation for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Those who attempt to force their way through a wall will not necessarily reach their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise opens no doors and builds no bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for increased maternity protection, in order to make progress here.

I believe that we truly need to seek an approach once again based on the Commission’s draft guidelines, incorporating greater flexibility for differing concepts in individual Member States, to significantly improve both maternity protection for women and protection for children during the first months of life.
That will not work with the draft presented here today, which certainly did not have the support of the majority, as some colleagues have attempted to make clear today.
I desire a little more flexibility here, a little more realism, and a better view of what the member states have already achieved, without calling our fundamental demands into question.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have done already.
Instead of preventing tax evasion, which would be sensible, instead of stopping loopholes for tax payers, one has produced here a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The proposed transition period of five months allows tax evaders ample time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert the assets stashed in Switzerland into a foundation asset.
The corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
The German tax authorities have recently received information regarding numerous tax evaders who have concealed their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax investigators are no longer permitted to further utilize the information available to them.
What kind of agreement is it that shackles the tax negotiations?
Accordingly, in an advertising video for Swiss banks, it states that customers will continue to benefit even more in the future from the values of the Swiss financial center regarding this agreement.

This agreement clearly lacks the necessary coordination at the EU level; it also runs counter to the EU’s efforts to enhance transparency in tax matters, to streamline tax collection in the Member States, and above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, it cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
We ask the EU to strongly advocate against it, if necessary.

Mr. President, thank you very much. In accordance with the rules of procedure of this assembly and in consultation with the parliamentary groups, I hereby request that this matter be referred back to the committees.
Madam President. I am pleased that, together with Roberta Angelilli's report, we have managed to launch a sustainable and effective directive, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: to this day, the vast majority of crimes occur within children’s closest social environment.
The perpetrators can be found within families, schools, and circles of acquaintances.
And here we still stand at the beginning of our work of enlightenment.

Therefore, our children must be empowered, strong enough to have the courage to confide in a trusted person in a serious situation, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when engaging with the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that a sense of responsibility in dealing with media plays a greater role in the education of our children.
In this context, education is of paramount importance, as many teachers and parents are simply unaware of what is possible with their children’s computers or mobile phones.
I believe there is a significant need for catch-up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as authorities, but also schools and families, must do everything possible to ensure that such abhorrent crimes do not occur in the first place.
Consequently, improved negotiation strategies for the EU with third countries, such as the United States and Russia, are also required.

Pages stored outside the EU can only be effectively and swiftly deleted if we also collaborate closely with these countries in the pursuit of the perpetrators and jointly send a clear signal of condemnation regarding the sexual abuse of children.
Once the perpetrator has been apprehended, the legislature has, unfortunately, often proven surprisingly lenient, suspending the majority of offenses only on probation.
Here, the severity of the offense should be more strongly considered in the future.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic encompasses a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, firefighting before barriers, legal precedent, public awareness, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after the coordination meeting tomorrow.
It is imperative that we do not remain idle.
Rather, we must accept the mandate for action, each and every one of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr. President. For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at roughly the same level.
In this process, the EU’s tasks have continually expanded, and the financial requirements have risen significantly.
Thus, new institutions necessary for financial market supervision have been established.
To effectively fulfill their tasks, however, these institutions require sound financial resources.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economies of these countries, a comprehensive stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the necessity of a Marshall Plan for the crisis-stricken EU countries.
The EU does not need austerity programs that stifle growth, but rather an expenditure program that promotes growth, one that secures work and income for workers and for young people in the EU.
Yet, what course of action does the council take in this situation?
He shortens the draft proposal, which already falls far short of necessities.

If, in the current political situation, a reasonable increase in the budget cannot be achieved, then Parliament and the Commission should nevertheless do everything possible to fend off the cuts proposed by the Council.
it is more difficult. Especially now in the crisis, it becomes clear what kind of European Union we actually want.
Do we want a union in which solidarity truly exists, such that we say it does not matter to us whether people must live in poverty in any Member State of the European Union?
we see ourselves as jointly responsible for fighting against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as has just been outlined by the colleagues from the far-right faction of this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that we, with the attitude of the member states and, in particular, of some governments of these member states, are dangerously close to that vision of a European Union as formulated by the far-right.
Do nothing shared, establish no shared instruments, establish no shared indicators, employ vague formulations wherever possible.
The third report makes this very clear on many points, and I believe we must become significantly stronger here.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We require social and ecological minimum standards.
Given the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here, we bear a shared responsibility—the responsibility as the European Union.
For that, we must advocate, and not for this nationalist drivel that we have heard from the right wing.

What advice would we have given our colleagues nineteen thirty-nine or nineteen thirty-eight, when we were in depression, when the financial markets had already undermined democracies, and when we were steering toward war?
I believe two things would be necessary: two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you must do, do not let yourself be slowed down, regulate every product, every institution, and every player like the Frau.
Mrs. Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, which enforces the financial emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no emergency program for democracy.

That means, in this case, naturally we need a European Community, naturally we need other treaties, naturally we need a mechanism that functions, but which only gains legitimacy if there are referendums.

And for that, we must now advocate that the situation has become so dramatic that a significant shift in perspective is necessary, before the right-wing extremists, before those who sow national division, regain control over something that was already being built.
Madam Chair. There is no doubt that this Assembly is committed to transparency and openness toward the citizenry.
My EPP Group does so as well, naturally.

Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are disregarded, and the protection of competitive procedures, sensitive, and personal data is disrespected.

Precisely this danger exists with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which may also include personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition proceedings.

With its vague, imprecise, and excessively broad definitions, the report permits public access even to such documents. This is because a document is defined as all data and content standing in any connection with the policies, measures, and decisions of all organs and institutions of the EU.
This includes preparatory, confidential, and secret documents, as well as all related information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents but also information.
Also, information from ongoing interinstitutional proceedings, such as from informal trilogue negotiations, should be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, because truly, what does that mean?

It means public access to the procedure, it means public influence on the decision-making process – then we might as well seat the lobbyists at the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizens want?
I cannot imagine it.
Furthermore, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organizations, etc., should also be published. Where is the public interest in that?
or would it not rather hinder our work?
I believe this report does not reflect the sentiments of our citizens.
He would unleash a flood of useless information.
He would make our work impossible, and above all, you’ve heard it from the commissioner. He is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates current regulations and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and fundamentally you are working against further transparency and against the citizen.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues,

When dealing with a topic as important and comprehensive as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, the risk is always considerable that one ends up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to accommodate their two or three favoured themes.
When one examines the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, there is no doubt that our rapporteur, Mathieu Grosch, deserves congratulations.

He managed to develop a good, coherent, and manageable result from several hundred proposed changes, which sets the primary emphasis for the future of transportation on safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social health and employment law conditions of employees are appropriately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming skills shortage in the transport sector, against which active measures must be taken if one wishes to prevent bottlenecks in well-trained specialists in the future.
Further liberalization of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given a prominent place here.
Road safety remains a topic that will continue to concern us in the future.
I view other points with greater criticality.
I would have preferred a statement concerning the Shift model, where more traffic would be shifted from the road to the rail network and waterways.
For this reason, I do not believe the discussion surrounding the "Giga-Aleiner" (large-scale single-use containers) represents the best solution for greater sustainability.
Equally critical, one should await and reconsider the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening of national passenger transport.
There remain technical harmonization and fair competitive conditions to resolve.

But as I said, in this report, I hope that expressing the expectations of Parliament here does not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by two thousand twenty and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.

My esteemed colleagues,

It has been only twenty years since the Central Asian states gained their statehood as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a lasting challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU’s relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and foster a spirit of partnership, but not to lead to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced child labor, remains an unfortunately widespread problem in many countries of the world that must be combated.

I do, however, wish to point out that it was customary in many agriculturally-shaped European regions to extend children’s school holidays during harvest time and to allow children from farming families the opportunity to assist with the harvest, which today would not be regarded as forced labor.
However, should there be indications of child forced labor during the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.
