The same consequence, however, must apply to all other states where child labour still exists, including those states in which we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or in China.
We should not apply double standards here.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues. I can only join the ranks here who have offered their congratulations to the Council Presidency.
You were not only an honest broker in difficult times, but you were also a European broker.
I believe that was very pleasant to feel in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a variety of member states that suggest to people that one can achieve more alone than together.
You have emphasized the common ground.
It was also very refreshing to witness that you, even in the domestic political debate, found support among the people in Poland with this clear European agenda.
That wasn't entirely straightforward in this context.
and also for that, the highest respect for what you have achieved.
We have been able to initiate quite a bit, particularly in the area of financial market regulation, over these past six months.

If I may single out just one area that I myself was able to negotiate, namely the question of regulation concerning short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose a strict regulation, where we were met by all

Member states were told, you will not prevail, and where, thanks to the Polish Council Presidency, it has been possible to sanction such a highly speculative instrument and where it is necessary to also prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my explicit thanks to your Finance Minister and the State Secretary, who initiated this through a laborious process of discussion between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Vice President, thank you very much.
Since yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has been in effect.
Meanwhile, the concrete substantive regulations are also now available.
Secondly, what developments does the Commission now consider dangerous, and what economic problems does it wish to correct?
A growth of hourly labor costs in Eurozone countries of more than three percent per year is considered a problem by the Commission.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not planned.
Inexpensive, dear Commission, does not necessarily mean good.
It is not enough to steer member states towards achieving prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, healthcare, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workers to the bone, but we will not write economic success stories.
Another example from the scoreboard: The loss of export market share should be reviewed and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With increasing global trade, Europe’s statistical shares inevitably decrease.
Consequently, the indicator penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we believe the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and subject it to a comprehensive overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. First and foremost, I would like to join in thanking our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report, because it is not a routine matter, even when engaging with competition policy for the fortieth time on the basis of a Commission report.

I owe the Commissioner a great deal of thanks, as the year two thousand ten was the year in which you were, for the first time, fully responsible for competition policy, for its very comprehensive presentation.

However, I would still like to express the request—as you also just mentioned in your contribution—that we are, particularly in the area of subsidies, of public subsidies in the banking sector, making some progress.
should occur, as a renewed capitalization within the banking sector is already being called for due to the European Banking Authority's new stress test.
I do not believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when, on the one hand, we still have a multitude of unresolved or unfinished legacy cases.
and in fact, new cases are already arising due to the corresponding pressure being built to increase the equity ratio, particularly within the private banking sector.

Therefore, here my most urgent request, Mr. Commissioner, to arrive at a swift resolution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector so that it can meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic of diffusion control will continue to occupy us significantly in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the clear and transparent path previously taken by the Commission within the framework of merger control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, particularly consumers, to ensure that competition remains possible, even in larger or different structures, in the area of merger control.
In that sense, I thank all those who have contributed here, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon arrive at a solution, particularly in the area of banking.

Mr. Commissioner, I believe you have hit the nail on the head when we all collectively observe that we are capable of initiating a third industrial revolution in Europe if we recognize the sustainability opportunities as an industrial chance.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that reminds me of a thought I completely forgot today.
I, in fact, forgot the human resources in my office.
Mrs. Philipp, allow me to say that you have worked tirelessly, and your successes are wonderful. You were a truly leading figure in this matter.
For this, I would like to express my gratitude.
Mr. President. To ensure freedom of speech in parliament, one also needs a functioning microphone system.
The button for turning on the microphone has broken on my device.
I would request that a technician restore the talk freedom.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. It astonishes me that we repeatedly have to be reminded of what structural and cohesion policy actually entails.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and it is defined as serving to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, while specifically promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been demonstrated particularly during the years of crisis.
Many regions anticipate even greater difficulties regarding economic development were these funds not available.
The implementation of Structural Funds support is based on operational programmes, as has already been noted, which describe the funding strategy of the respective region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions collaborate here in a partnership, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the resources made available and standing by.

Therefore, I am very surprised when, repeatedly, from member states and, as we now see, also from the Commission's side, there are attempts to treat Structural Funds as a savings account for all manner of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the purpose and objectives of cohesion policy and, moreover, unsettles the actors in the regions who are already working towards achieving the goals based on long-term strategies and agreements.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and advocating for economic growth are important objectives.

This will only be achieved, however, if the collaborative partnership between the regions, the Member States, and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy represents the unifying, cooperative, and solidarity-based framework for action between the various levels of governance within the European Union.
In it, solidarity in Europe becomes visible locally, in the regions, and it should not be lightly abandoned due to political rash decisions.

Mr. President, Commissioner. I support the compromise reached in the trilogue, which is intended to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not resolve all the problems currently faced by dairy farmers in some Member States.
Already, Commissioner Mantzolt, fifty years ago within the framework of the CAP preferential measures had stipulated the creation of producer organizations.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry, owing to the high proportion of grassland, is the primary pillar of our agriculture.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to unite in a cooperative that handles the processing of the milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirements of a soft-landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative with regard to legislative proposals, and therefore I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament by 2012 to remedy this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the super levy, charged per kilogram of milk delivered, until 2015, or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation, without harming member states not affected by it.
The present milk package is also to be understood as the final report of the High Level Group, which aims to bring about a soft landing for the abolition of milk quotas.
Remarkably, there is no mention of milk quotas at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and in four other member states, who are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production,
to compete on the global market after 2015, they can only do so by purchasing quotas even now, shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
a tremendous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that disadvantages you compared to your colleagues in twenty-two member states. Thank you.
Very well, Bibelukat. A question. Are you aware that we have community bonds already?
and that the resolution does not speak of euro bonds in a general sense, but rather of very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have again isolated generalities about Euro Bonds here.
And precisely this level of differentiation, which we have achieved here with Ms. Goulart’s excellent proposal, we should not relinquish.
I would appreciate a bit more differentiation in your statements and am eager to hear your thoughts on the matter.
I simply want to state briefly, dear colleague Goulart, that this is not an assessment I have made here.
I merely want to point out that the last Italian government bond, before Italy joined the Euro, yielded ten percent.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take that over now.
It was, of course, standard practice to pay high interest rates.

And now suddenly, because we have had ten years of low interest rates and accumulated excessive debt, because money has become cheap for investments as well as for public coffers, then one wants to prolong this through Euro Bonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Mr. President. Commissioner, your response has rather disappointed me.

You evidently want to retain the existing system, which necessitates complicated negotiations per country and, in turn, restricts further access to literature, meaning fewer opportunities will arise for blind and visually impaired individuals.
This makes it all the more saddening for me, because the European Union is now blocking a step forward at WIPO, while all other contracting parties would be willing to move ahead.
Here, a tremendous opportunity is being missed.

You are not fighting here for more rights for authors, but rather you are fighting against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and to enable them to participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you. Please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding treaty.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues. The discussion here in this chamber demonstrates that we essentially represent the entire spectrum: on one side, those who desire no restrictions whatsoever, and on the other, those who equate every form of immigration with the threat of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this framework.
I believe one must consider family reunification with great reason and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States where unduly restrictive measures are being taken.
for family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that, in the end, no one can be reunited at all.
On the other hand, it is entirely legitimate for member states to, for example, require language proficiency, to require integration, but also to require a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States naturally have the right, and we should not brush aside these issues, the problems that arise in the context of family reunification, to articulate them.

If countries like Greece or Malta, or indeed Romania or Italy, are no longer permitted to articulate the problems they face, in part within this context, then I do not know whether we are democratic if we simply ignore issues.
I don’t believe we need to introduce another new guideline just yet.
We should carefully discuss the problems and then consider how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to an improvement in the guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing implementation challenges in some areas.

However, I also fully understand the need for us to first address the fact that we shouldn't be creating another new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the existing directive's issues in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and, at the same time, respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
If one proceeds with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will arrive at a good path.
Mr. President. Consider, before you think, advises the Polish aphorist Stanisław Jürgelewicz, and this recommendation would occasionally serve us well in this parliament as well.
Weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy, adopted in this house, which granted censorship to the Central Asian states, strike events in Jarnao Zend are now also…
in Kazakhstan, reflected without awaiting the results of ongoing investigations conducted with international participation.

However deeply the deceased are to be mourned, and however the injured and those detained as a result of these events have a right to the processing of what transpired, the underlying reasons remain opaque.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, stated, "This was a group of other people. The unrest simply does not serve the interests of the strikers, as it merely provides the pretext for acting against them with force."
The Central Asia expert Arkadi Dubnov also stated, "It cannot be ruled out that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad are also involved."
On the other hand, however, it could suit someone in the Kazakh capital, Astana, quite well to maintain the tensions.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan’s power elites are already vying for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition here in Parliament in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador.

The UN Special Representative Miroslav Jenszak announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government’s consideration of the events of Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to reveal the true background of the UN.
We should take the Kasharian authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but not arrive at reflexive prejudgments.
If I understand you correctly, the statement you made today is yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the most vulnerable people in the European Union.
She will do everything to put concrete proposals on the table in the foreseeable future—regarding where the program will be located and how financing will be secured.
I consider this to be urgently necessary and believe that we share a collective responsibility to ensure that this food program actually becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because, from my perspective, it is a signal to show people that we still have a fundamental sense of the necessary solidarity with the

the life situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, have not been able to participate in a development and who have become the first and the greatest victims of the European Union’s approach to managing the crisis.
I am thinking of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where precisely what we do as the European Union primarily impacts the poorest and most vulnerable.
We set a marker, but it is no longer there.
I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary that we not only show consideration for the eighteen million people in the European Union who, at this time, depend on the food that
must be made available, but rather that it must be the case. We want to place the fight against poverty consistently, or at least initially, at the top of our own agenda, on the very top spot.
This signal we have not conveyed yet.

That, from my perspective, is the decisive point if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union, to truly shape a social and solidarity-based Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking change their stance.
I believe that is also a matter of self-commitment for us.
Esteemed Colleague Daul, I have listened attentively to you.
What you propose—to include a growth assessment for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity assessment—essentially means narrowing the objectives to growth.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the demands of a Christian Democratic faction, which surely still has aims beyond growth.
It should be generally known that the economy does not bring children into the world that it does not raise and cannot provide them with a life in an intact nature.
This suggests, therefore, that priorities are being altered by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are being reconsidered.
As a parliamentary group, we will very carefully examine whether what you presented this morning truly constitutes a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: First the economy, which requires functioning financial markets.
Initially, the focus was on restructuring public finances, that is, reducing debt and calming the markets.
Mr. Dohl, who is unfortunately not present, I actually only wanted to tell him that I would handle it exactly as Georges Machet would.
I may not have understood his answer, but I would still contradict him.
I believe the measures that have been initiated were simply wrong.
You were not correct; it was not correct to focus exclusively on the restoration of the economy while completely disregarding what was happening to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the Euro above all else and to say that what becomes of the people is entirely of no concern to us.
It must be the other way around. First, it concerns the people, then we can continue discussing Euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain drove the interest rates on Spanish government bonds above six percent, bringing them close to the level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal, or indeed Ireland sought support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policy imposed on member states by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF, with its drastic reductions in public expenditure of all kinds.
Wage and pension cuts, increases in value-added tax, and much more have placed the burden squarely on citizens, rather than preventing the renewed spiral.
Rigorous cuts in state spending exacerbate the recession, drive up states’ debt ratios, and that must be our common understanding.
When Mr. Draghi recently stated that the European social model is at an end, I am pleased, Mr. Barroso, when you say no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to meticulously register what transpires there.
What happens to those people who currently have to fight for survival?
What happens, or what do we do together, to finally break this spiral of self-destruction that is currently taking hold in the countries most affected by debt?
It simply cannot be that we stand here idly by.
And we benefit neither from social-political programs that will only take effect when other measures have already proven successful.

We must act now.
Where have your objectives from the 2020 strategy disappeared to
for combating poverty?
What has become of the European Platform Against Poverty?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the action of the European Union.
You do not need empty promises.
We require concrete ideas regarding what actions should be taken now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those within the Commission who have also recognized the signs of the times and want to change things.
But please don't simply continue and say it will be alright.

Nothing more will come of it if things continue like this. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can now truly and actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it.
We will have to do it in our countries, to prevent being blocked and to ensure that funding for the ESF – from 2013 or 2014 to 2020, or indeed for the other programs – is not reduced.
that the Member States fulfill their responsibilities.
Esteemed colleagues. The current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairy tale regarding fiscal policy.
The situation in the council is, quite simply, that little progress is made there regarding fiscal policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation.
You benefit from aggressive tax planning; you are tax havens yourselves.
And the contracts explicitly stipulate unanimous agreement on tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered setbacks with its proposals.
They are diluted, they do not progress, as with the interest rate directive, and in more recent proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested at all in a spirit of anticipatory compliance.

Therefore, Mr. Schemeter, I understand that your job is not easy in this regard, so please change the strategy, propose decisive measures, and then rely on intensified cooperation to end the blocking position in the council.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. The present proposal concerning risk-sharing instruments will certainly not prevent state bankruptcy where it is destined to occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
Exceptional situations sometimes require exceptional measures.

The budgetary and debt crisis in some states has led to such an exceptional situation that important projects and measures within cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented, because the banking sector is failing as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
An exceptional measure, I see in the present proposal for the creation of risk-sharing instruments to refinance projects in structural policy.
Instruments of cohesion and structural policy available to Länder that wish to utilize these division instruments can be employed to provide financial security for ongoing projects.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Ms. Danuta Hübner, for her significant contribution to the clarification of the Commission’s proposal and for once again clearly outlining when and how these instruments should be utilized.
I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments must be attributable solely to the current situation and cannot constitute a prejudice for the future funding period.

As in the most recent amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in the year two thousand nine, when it was stipulated that a review should be conducted after three years and four studies presented, our faction supported that.
and indeed also because she had repeatedly raised significant concerns for data protection law reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in passports.

Belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this means, and the consequences that result from it, along with the underestimation of other links in the security chain, are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that it is immutable and the most trustworthy.
That is quite otherwise.
These data, too, are changeable over the course of a lifetime.
In children, they appear differently than in old age.
And for that very reason, reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
We have now been able to ascertain this.
As is repeatedly demonstrated in Great Britain and other countries, the chips are in no way secure against misuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean lasting damage for those affected.
Even the standards within the EU are extraordinarily varied.
The error rate is very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
Again and again, the question must be asked: what use are biometric data if documents are forged and circulating?
Therefore, if a link in the chain is forged, if the originating documents are inconsistent, biometric data is unlikely to be of further assistance to us.
A final demonstration: The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, instant adhesive, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. Within a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. So much for the supposed security.
We expect the commission to submit the studies, and of course, also the results and the consequences that can be derived from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, the commission is unfortunately not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for the Parliament.

As a member of parliament from a region that will be severely affected by the planned changes – namely, the Eiffel – after careful observation of the debate, the question arises as to whether the unfortunately only marginally viable attempt

whether a standardization of criteria for disadvantaged areas truly addresses the needs in these regions, particularly as the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is currently lacking.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficiently comprehensive impact assessment was truly conducted.
To do justice to farmers, we require not only biophysical criteria, but also socioeconomic criteria in addition.

Therefore, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, independently of the overall package of CAP reform, and above all after the presentation of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the implications, regarding the criteria.

I do indeed believe that we must also work, in collaboration with the asylum support office and the Greek authorities, to identify more quickly which individuals who have arrived in Greece may, in fact

can also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly, they can definitively never return to their country of origin, and secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that can be of benefit to all.
Fundamentally, however, it is also about assisting the Greeks in enabling registration and identification more rapidly, in order to facilitate faster aid processes.

to return those to their home countries who neither possess the qualifications nor the authorization to remain in Greece or the European Union, because they would have realistically had the opportunity to stay in their own countries of origin.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Madam Commissioner, and thank you also to the rapporteur for her consistently dedicated and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, I can share, support, or have partially supported.
However, there inevitably comes a point at which one must assume responsibility.
And for the EPP, or indeed for myself, I therefore also maintain that we must now address ourselves to realities and cannot retreat into ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the USA have been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact is, we all don't want the data traffic to be able to be stopped, even with a negative attitude; we don't want to be able to stop the data traffic at all.
You had just done that.
It is also a fact that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to cease.
And the fact is also that the USA has a right to know who is entering its country.
And my assessment is also that the legal services have orally stated to us all that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
And that is what we were elected for.
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone and with fewer protections and rights.
would leave the airlines – and the commissioner had emphasized this – in a state of absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility, however, also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, but also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are, in sum, also in favor of approving this agreement, even taking into consideration that it is not perfect, but precisely because of its consequences.
If one wishes to better protect citizens and to provide them with improved data protection, one also assumes this responsibility and approves of this agreement. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. You have given us most illuminating remarks.
Thank you very much for that.

Numbers sometimes say more than grand words, and to this day, the European Parliament – as you also mentioned – has granted almost two patents on plants and nearly twelve patents on animals, which originated both with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the granting of patents on genetically modified and bred barley—this applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Consequently, our farmers, brewers, producers, and indeed we consumers are affected.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example: the so-called long-life tomato – not to be confused with its long-life oil, which you have in your diesel engines.
With this tactic employed by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in violation of valid EU regulations.
What was not patented was the tomato itself, but rather its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This demonstrates the method employed here and that, although it, as you stated, Mr. Commissioner, is clearly stipulated in Article Four of the Biopatent Directive of nineteen ninety-nine, plant varieties and animal breeds, and a and b essentially biological procedures for breeding plants or animals, are not patentable.
We believe this definition must be clarified; it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures employed to assist conventional breeding must not lead to patentability in its entirety.
We are not claiming a patent on life, specifically.
And we need a clear signal here for greater ethics and for greater honesty in our dealings with creation, once again against patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Mr. Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are prohibited in Europe and will remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article Four of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.

Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we demand a clear and unambiguous codification of the breeder’s and farmer’s privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you very much.
Madam Chair, I would like to address the dissolution of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol, there is little to no cause for criticism.

The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in all material respects as of two thousand ten, and all underlying transactions are compliant with regulations and, consequently, lawful.
Notably, the high transfers stand in contrast to the overall, actually low accumulated costs.
Europol attributes this to a relocation to new headquarters, which is, of course, understandable.
But Europol pledges to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly control of the budget's execution from 2012 onwards.
I recommend we keep track of this to ensure it actually happens.
Against this backdrop, I recommend relieving the burden on Europol.
Regarding Eurojust, the financial statement also reflects the financial situation in two thousand ten in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and compliant with regulations.
But here too, high operating expenses were carried over to the year 2011.
Following Eurojust’s justification, this was primarily due to an organizational structure project involving a new computer infrastructure and costs associated with data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better adherence to tender requirements.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
It has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to AURIUS.
I still recommend relief.
Madam President, distinguished Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What should alarm and cause us to panic is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed individuals increased by 26.5 percent, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only decoupling an entire generation from the labor market, we are decoupling an entire generation from a future worth living.
When we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they turn away from this EU, because they lack reasonable employment and life prospects.

Mr. Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize a number of things, but please ensure that this long-standing intellectual stagnation does not now transform into operational frenzy.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people, when applying abroad, are now also to be financially supported, then we are organizing a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it will prove counterproductive; then technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff will be poached from states that are wealthier, states not experiencing this crisis.
Now, in this crisis, the cause of which is, offensive measures are needed—namely, the dismantling of this austerity mania that is affecting the European economy.
We need a targeted growth policy; we need a strengthening of domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With a combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop a truly integrated concept that offers young people a perspective for life.

Final Remark

This situation of youth unemployment also tolerates no nonsense; the idea of raising the retirement age for people to seventy is unacceptable.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I earnestly request my thanks.
Colleague, you have just stated that everything arguing in favor of a financial transaction tax would be speculation, and then proceeded to offer very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what you think of these investigations by the Commission, which very clearly state that, thus far, insufficient attention has been paid to the real economy and its dependence on

to the financial markets that, in other words, ninety-five of the companies are in no way dependent on borrowing, and that a negative growth effect, which has been discussed thus far, can indeed be turned into a positive one by implementing appropriate public investments that promote growth.
Is that merely speculation for you as well, or would you say that such a well-founded, comprehensive study by the Commission is justified and constitutes a strong argument?

Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues,

The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She does, at the very least, embrace the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation and, above all, of making them bear a share of the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
That is also a very important signal to citizens, to our voters.
In a number of member states, there were numerous actions, from petitions to written appeals to politicians, urging the introduction of a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe the parliament has achieved a significant success with the majority that is emerging here for this report regarding this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as perhaps would be necessary, but I believe it is a truly important step that has been taken here.
I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to advocate for
that a genuine introduction takes place, that it is not blocked in the council due to the British position or other positions, the introduction of this tax.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I believe it is a significant responsibility.

It now rests in the Council’s hands to act here, and I would like to use my allotted time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues. I believe that, despite all the detailed issues that we can and must discuss, and over which we will still need to deliberate in the further legislative process, we should agree on one thing in the
be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to the model where banks pocket the profits when everything goes well, and taxpayers foot the bill when something goes wrong.
And therefore, it makes sense to also subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do that transnationally.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we wouldn’t have distortions, but rather we would continuously contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies

Access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or to set something aside for retirement, and that financial markets thus fulfill the task for which they were originally created: to provide added value for the real economy.
All of that which drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

Therefore, it makes sense to contribute through taxation to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is steered, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its function.
Therefore, I advocate for the adoption of this proposal today with a large majority.
The reform of the general preferential system was certainly necessary.
It is now advantageous that there are longer durations and that there is greater security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the development committee has already stated.
The committee unfortunately refers only to World Bank classifications.
In this regard, Parliament has repeatedly and critically examined gross domestic product as the sole criterion in the past.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with four to twelve U.S. dollars of gross domestic product.
This represents, therefore, a vast and far too extensive range, and does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
That countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are eliminated, we certainly do not find concerning.
The reform in that direction was therefore sound.
But these are, in any case, high-income countries.
Russia and China are countries with upper-middle income status, regarding which we need not, of course, be concerned about their falling out of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Hitherto, the Commission had also at least considered the vulnerability criterion, namely countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on the export of few products and are therefore particularly vulnerable from being rated too highly.
Why did the Commission then strike out this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will therefore be excluded, even though their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why did the commission not continue with the existing criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
The suspicion arises that the Commission intends to compel poorer countries into free trade agreements that are disadvantageous to them.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region plays no further role.
Fortunately, however, colleagues in the plenary session will still have the opportunity to approve our amendment, which incorporates vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to commercial regions being torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to adhere to different rules when exporting to the EU.
That has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The commission should give greater consideration to development regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, we Greens have submitted an amendment that we hope will garner widespread support.
It is also problematic when countries that yesterday still benefited from the APS are to be dropped from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not sufficient for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we, as members of parliament, must also consider whether, in all legislative proposals, we want to focus solely on speed and then work with skewed compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire assembly.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and also for democracy; it is not time or speed that are important, but rather time and democracy are needed in order to do so and to properly enact laws. Thank you.

Mr. President, Honorable Representative. I, too, was a member of the European Parliament’s election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to ascertain the considerable hope and expectation for a better future with which people lined up and waited at the polling stations to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Democratic Republic of the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as colleague Nedelcheva also did in her report.
The former president, Josef Kabila, has declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and whether third states such as Rwanda are involved remains unclear.
Those who suffer are, in any case, the civilian population, which has now for decades been unable to live in peace and quiet.
The country’s wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption, and the Congo remains at the very bottom of all international evaluations.

The international community, and particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of the Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He has an opportunity with the upcoming regional elections.

to that end, and that the Congolese army not only ceases to harass the civilian population but also apprehends and transfers internationally wanted perpetrators of crimes against humanity, such as Bosco and Daganga, to a court of law.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any further weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, the human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Madam President. The Tupac [resolution] aims to create further intervention rights against crisis countries within the Eurozone.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission’s intention, Member States should be able to be compelled to accept financial assistance.
The Sixpack has already created extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible instrument for economic policy coordination.
Simultaneously, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with exclusion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong choice in Sunday's election.
Why do we not cease these degrading and undemocratic displays of menace?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically intensified, I think of Spain, of Cyprus—it does not help us to publicly denounce member states that are struggling in the crisis.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of the Tupac have indeed developed sensible approaches to this end.

Elisa Ferreira's reference to the redemption fund is certainly worthwhile.
That would be a valuable and sensible measure to combat debt.
Perhaps, however, also Jean Paul Gauzet's proposal for an orderly state insolvency.
Crucially, however, it is that Europe is undertaking a joint and solidarity-based effort to return the Eurozone to a path of growth.
The stronger nations in Europe must cease to be self-satisfied and point fingers at their partner countries.
You must begin doing your homework, invest in growth, and take responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy a la Merkel has simply failed as a crisis solution.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the heads of state or government of the EU finally recognized that the European Community needs a more coordinated fiscal and economic policy.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is entirely correct that members of an Economic and Monetary Union must not solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.

An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents member states with a significant temptation: to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can lead to the economic and political disintegration of the monetary union.
The EU is currently facing precisely such a situation.

For years, the German economy has drained the resources of its neighbors, failing to generate impetus through investment and wage growth; instead, Berlin has nearly driven the Eurozone to ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is now slowly getting to the heart of this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making corresponding proposals.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic of Germany is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare, and quite rightly the Commission is being called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to adjust wage growth to productivity growth.
That is a late, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will vigorously advocate this demand before the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, particularly to Commissioner Barnier, for a very simple reason: because the experiences from the previous legislative period, the one preceding 2009…

was that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal of the European private company came about, the predecessor of Mr. Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, had essentially let company law sleep a deep sleep. We, in these five years concerning this important matter, which is also significant for the internal market,
have progressed.
Thank goodness that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there is a wide range of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has developed concerning the further development of company law, and we now have a very current consultation, with which we, as Parliament, are naturally also engaging.

The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, and that is simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Mr. Commissioner Barnier, and simultaneously, in a subsequent resolution, to clearly define our position as Parliament regarding what should happen next.
I believe that it is necessary, similarly to what we had approximately ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law, and that for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European social law, genuine gaps, which essentially result in the internal market not being established.
I would like to cite the absence of the Fourteenth Directive on the Transfer of Registered Offices as an example, which, in my view, represents a very typical instance of such a lacuna.
The Parliament has called for this twice in the legislative initiative reports, requesting that the European Commission put forward concrete proposals on this matter.
There is also the expert panel, which the European Commission itself appointed, that has likewise expressed the same opinion on the matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms within the single market that a company must also be able to move within the single market with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also simultaneously criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous statement on the Fourteenth Directive actually falls considerably short of Parliament’s expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, within the scope of the further work, should an action plan materialize, this proposal will hopefully be incorporated into the action plan.
Another important aspect of corporate law is the question of the continued development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens on businesses.
Here, we already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example, regarding the topic of
But I believe, furthermore, there is also more to do and further aspects that will also be clarified within the scope of the consultation.
Here, we also anticipate further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the commission to revive the topic of the European Private Company, which is currently stalled in the Council.

If there are individual member states – and I may express my own opinion here – if there are individual member states within the EU that, due to a lack of their own decisiveness, are not able to resolve this deadlock on their own,

To move Europe forward, it is necessary here, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, to occasionally consider utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the commission to reconsider this matter with particular emphasis.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, that is, a sort of Rome Regulation for cross-border issues in corporate law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion and would request that the commission undertake this task.
This is also closely related.
We have insolvency law, but it is already announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission within a foreseeable timeframe.
You see, in corporate law, there is an enormous amount to be done.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has once again taken the initiative, and that it is apparent that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then represent progress in shaping the internal market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in its approach.

Regarding the details, one will naturally address them.
That we must certainly do.
But for that, I also need thanks to the commission.
We would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to take up our initiatives and translate them into concrete proposals.
Dear Commissioner, I highly value your proposal concerning a performance-related pay policy.
But on the matter of the minimum wage, you balked at Mrs. Merkel, and I do not believe you regarding the expansion of employment in the healthcare sector.
How can new work possibly be created there, when the Commission has already compelled southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by as much as half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector arise when, in the new state-specific recommendations for the European Semester, the Commission is compelling some member states to further reduce healthcare spending?
I fear this point in the plan is pure announcement policy, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medications, not only in Greece.
I believe that whoever consistently provides new safety nets for banks must now focus on a safety net for the people, particularly for securing medical care in crisis-stricken countries. Thank you.
The mood among unfortunate pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened dismay over what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, at the very least, gratifying that what we are dealing with is now stated much more clearly, and that the eyes are not closed even regarding Italy.
You are well aware that you are caught in a series of traps, not only in those of debt and growth, but also in the trap of trust and in the trap of power, esteemed Commission and also the Council.
You have, unfortunately, failed thus far to address the central question of detaching the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here will, in expert opinion, repeatedly be assessed as the shadow banking sector continuing to lack serious boundaries.
We are also still dealing with systemic risks, the question of “too big to fail” remains inadequately addressed, and there is little point in speaking about the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, and also advise you, if you are now working toward the European Council meeting, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing this power question between the real and the financial economy.

To put it succinctly, that you finally work in a credible manner before the European citizens to ensure that banks are brought under control and that it is not always the citizens who bear the burden.

Dear Colleague Färm, you come from a country that rejected the euro, albeit largely on the grounds that it wishes to preserve the flexibility of devaluation, not least for reasons relating to social policy instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone, in order to actively utilize this socio-political instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environmental Committee by a substantial majority, with sixty-two votes in favor, zero votes against, and no abstentions.
That demonstrates that we are actually very closely aligned there, even concerning compromises.

And naturally, the highest priority in this legislative process must be a high level of protection, strong consumer protection, particularly for the most vulnerable members of our society, for children in need of protection.
As far as gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem, and particularly so in daycare centers.
Looking around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances prevalent there, I believe we made the right choice.
We should also discuss this among ourselves in the second reading, with advice, with the committee.
I believe that we will also arrive at a good result.

Mr. President. A report regarding a traffic accident over the weekend involving a truck driver who fell asleep due to exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control through a digital tachograph is essential—for us, for road safety, but also for those affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation. It presents new problems, but also retains older ones.
The new problems arise from new opportunities for manipulation, which we must also manage technically.
These are the old problems—those that we can, so to speak, observe in various member states either during control or due to a lack thereof.
What we are now newly regulating, in my view, has to consider fundamentally first, that not every time when no journey is recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers involve loading and unloading, and this is, of course, to be considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records have been removed from the dossier.
I consider that to be incorrect, as there are also significant accident risks here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline so that fraud can be reported, anonymously and tracked.
What I will also submit is a proposal that animal transport controls be incorporated into this regulation.
I consider this important, because this too must be a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many people might still be alive today, or would not suffer from permanent disabilities, had professional medical assistance been provided quickly enough, that is, within the first so-called “golden hour,” following their accident.
We would be a good deal closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system, about which we are speaking today, cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve one of the initial duty to provide assistance.
It serves solely to automatically inform an emergency call center in the event of a severe accident.
This must also establish verbal contact with the accident vehicle to avoid misuse and overload due to minor accidents.
Only when the emergency call has been confirmed or no one responds further are emergency physicians dispatched to the scene of the accident, equipped with limited but life-threatening information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain rests subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, transmitting no signals or data and being unlocatable.
It is, therefore, also far superior from a data protection perspective to a mobile telephone.
The system becomes active only with automatic activation controlled by sensors or with deliberate manual triggering.
It then transmits a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to a rescue coordination center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data, upon arrival, are recognized, assessed, and processed as emergency calls.
Therefore, member states must also upgrade and expand their emergency response chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-harmonized emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to function everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
These can also later support other intelligent public transport services such as real-time traffic information or parking availability.

In recognition of the automotive industry's outstanding achievements in providing in-vehicle emergency call systems, these should retain their validity alongside the public emergency call system based on 112.
Users can also decide in favor of such a system based on detailed information.
This may be accompanied by costs, as the case may be.
Use of the data by workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

For if this brewery or beverage distributor is seven kilometers away from my place of residence, I will no longer have any chance of them continuing to offer me their goods in the future, without them having to purchase a new tachograph, without new bureaucracy arising.

Therefore, I voted against this resolution today, because I am of the opinion that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we managed to include, which was positive, thank God.
It was initially planned to accept only distances of fifty kilometers within the scope of a regional provider.
That was utterly absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
Thus, one hundred kilometers are perhaps just about manageable.
But what if it extends beyond that?
I consider it excessive.
And as a final point, representing a workers' organization within the CSU, I would also say that we are creating complete oversight of employees with this regulation.
Why?
because, for example, the person who provides goods for construction or for beverages, for breweries, is monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
Therefore, I also consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, for data protection reasons, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Thank you very much for this question.
why I am not waiting for this decision.

I awaited the European People’s Party’s approval in the Legal Affairs Committee, while we were still raising the necessary questions concerning legal certainty with regard to ACTA during the process itself.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is what you did not want. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used to cause delay, that is clear.
why I said that about the broad scope for interpretation.
Because you have, in fact, posed two questions, I must answer both of them; that is unfortunately the case.
because, namely, from these expansive formulations, the monitoring of the internet, the auxiliary police ISPs, can extract and interpret everything.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not help our economy, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you entirely opposed to the rejection of all intellectual property?
And how do you envision the E-Commerce Directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject debate on these matters altogether and do not uphold intellectual property rights.
Is that correct, or how should I look at it?
Mr. President. This is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question: How do we treat democracy and fundamental rights?
And when we examine ACTA, we find that it, in a way, represents opacity, a lack of democracy, and a violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.

and, in a sense, undemocratic, because the free use of the internet simply might no longer be possible afterwards, and neither might the freedom to utilize generics to the extent that has been the case thus far.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and already voted on ACTA.
Yes, there has been voting on ACTA in the streets, on the internet, regarding the petitions committee in many countries, not only within the EU, but also
Also outside the EU. We must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy from many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you to file ACTA away; that would be proper.

Madam President, Madam Council President. As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency concerning the budgetary rules. This establishes a set of rules for the coming MFF period and the OLAF procedure.
Since November two thousand eight, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this procedure to completion based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would like to thank you, therefore, for two exceptionally dedicated tax officials who handled these dossiers, and also Ambassador Trankommsen.
You will be missed. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have truly rendered a great service to the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen,

I am speaking here now as a representative of my parliamentary group and would like to support the motion proposed by Colleague Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates careful handling of the subject of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has put forward to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion in order to clarify still-open questions.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone dictates that we await this decision.
There is objectively no reason whatsoever to make this decision today.
No one will be prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that is then made occurs in a different consciousness, in a different understanding than today's.
I do not mean that rogue drivers on the internet highway should determine our politics, and for that reason my request is to support this motion. Thank you.
As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very insightful, and one wishes that what he says had much greater influence on European policy.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a sensible idea, but only if they are sustainability-oriented and if the necessary political framework is established for them.
We risk insuring against risks that we do not have politically under control through guarantees.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require 3,800 kilometers of grid network; only 100 kilometers of these corresponding high-voltage transmission networks have been built, partly due to resistance from the public – incidentally, a very ecologically-minded public.
We need to come up with something politically.

One idea would be to create shared TEN-corridors, meaning not only to combine high-speed railway lines and broadband networks, but also, perhaps above them and alongside the motorway, to construct the corresponding grid networks.
This, however, requires a far more comprehensive planning than has been foreseen thus far, but I would at least like to suggest this here.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements within the European Union. However, I am also aware that borders remain a very sensitive issue for our member states, and will continue to be so.
I am aware that the problems existing between Member States regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There exist various problems.
Ignoring problems does not make them better, nor does it resolve them more effectively.
I live near the border with the Czech Republic, and here, nobody would ever consider wanting to close the border again, merely because we have problems.
But I also request the Commission’s support in this area, and not limitations or rejections.
The veil scanning has been implemented because we want to ensure security while simultaneously maintaining freedom of movement.
And if we carry out the border checks successfully, I anticipate also at the borders with the Czech Republic, where one or two drug dealers are not only involved in a few cases, but in many.

If they are attempting to gain transitional access in many cases, then I believe it is good if the German Federal Interior Minister and his Czech counterpart were to meet to jointly resolve the problems that exist at the border.
And this is something the Commission should not influence through regulation, but rather positively and supportively.

We want to contain the populists but resolve the real problems together. Therefore, I also ask the Council to work with the Parliament to find a solution that will allow us to successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of movement while simultaneously guaranteeing the security of citizens.

Madam President. The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by Parliament in its question also demonstrate why the Council wishes to keep Parliament essentially outside the Schengen process.
The Council, however, intends to continue undermining freedom of movement without involving Parliament, without any form of parliamentary oversight, without any form of public accountability.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat yourselves on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.

It is no surprise that the German government, without evaluation, wants to rule out an evaluation of the internal borders entirely and thus does not want to examine how much freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen, however, does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and therefore also belongs in the European Parliament. Thank you.
Mr. President, it is a special moment for me and for my faction today to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person stands at the head of the EU whom we consider to be part of our political family.
You assume the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is imperative to determine the course the European Union will take.
whether the Union will actually have a future or whether it will prove to be a historical defeat, amounting to a footnote in history—that, from my perspective, would be the case.
Following the conversations we have had with you, with representatives of your government, and with the chairs of factions and parties in your country, I know that you are committed to this.
that you have prepared for your presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the magnitude of your responsibility.
But you have also made this clear here today: you intend to consciously direct the attention of those in power to the living situation of people.
I can tell you that, after everything I’ve heard in recent years, it is the first time a President of the European Union actually does and announces and says precisely this tone.
I have long missed this in official speeches—that it be said: This is about the people, about those who are not responsible for this crisis, yet who bear the brunt of it.
It will be difficult to implement precisely this approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be gained, and you will do so as well, I am very certain, if you, above all, the people with your presidency and the way you
to exercise the right to advocate for their rights and to contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which, I also see, is important for the functioning of the European Union and the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions that were defined.

It can never be the aim of the European Union to accept, for the sake of the functioning of the euro, that people within the European Union must hunger, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local administrations must cease their work.
Something has gone amiss here.
It is not what we can designate as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that the focus be on social cohesion and solidarity, both among the individual member states and between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union must not simply allow itself to be used as an instrument or as a spokesperson for a small, specific stratum of the population, nor present itself in that way.

And one final point I would also like to address, naturally, to underscore that everything you have also mentioned in your priorities is important to us, and that we will also support the points that move in that direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people no longer live in fear.
Fear is the worst counselor for democracies.
I believe that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly concerning the elections in Greece and the votes on the referendum in Ireland, were also influenced by fear.
And if those in power in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Wishing you much success in your work.
Dear colleagues, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be very important for the colleague to work on this dossier swiftly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

Currently, eyes are on us and on the Council, urging us to take this step – to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through further European integration, specifically through a European banking union.
It must be said that Parliament already requested this two years ago with a broad majority.
We have conducted twenty-six trilogues.
We have taken a step in that direction, but unfortunately not as far as would actually have been necessary.
Further billions in invoices have arisen as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wishes to further deepen this step for the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
The decision of the Council that the ECB should become the location for Eurozone supervision, however, is associated with certain difficulties.
In the council, this leads to unanimity, and it results in the parliament not having a shared decision-making role in this dossier.
Following experiences with the supervisory package, this is unacceptable.

Therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal regarding the changes at the ECB with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby establishing in practice the principle of parliamentary democratic participation.
Democratically, there are further challenges as well.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has not previously had any tasks.

If she now assumes responsibility within banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary powers, full control powers, the right to question, and appointment powers—and I am certain that Parliament will assert these rights with a broad majority.

We will thoroughly discuss in the coming weeks the complex questions regarding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility. Thank you.
Mr. President. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.
These freedom chapters, as the term economic partnerships suggests, revolve solely around the interests of the EU and not around the development interests of the partner countries.
That runs completely counter to the EU’s objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with it.
Countries like Cameroon, Côte d'Ivoire, and Namibia would be significantly affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects like those in Southeast Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and thereby only suggest that other countries kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission genuinely believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Committee on Development of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission’s proposal.
We should join that in plenary session.
