Mr. President. Both in Central America and in Peru and Colombia, there are an immense number of problems in the area of human rights.
And we, as Members of the European Parliament, cannot simply turn a blind eye to it.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights, requested by the EU in the cases of Colombia and Peru, when it is then established.
It must possess substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of perpetrators and the safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And naturally, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is correct that the Committee on Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the draft regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue, however, must then also confirm it, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
Indeed, the EU must do far more to keep a close watch on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.

Therefore, as the Green Party, we are also demanding a proper impact assessment prior to each negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU but also the effects on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I had already made it clear in the first round what I would like to emphasize.
My concern relates to the expectation of my group from the Commission that it once again accommodates the Troika in the relevant committees, to clearly and distinctly state We as

We, as a commission, as a European institution, stand for the principle that people should not be driven further into poverty, that working hours should not be reduced, and that ecological and social standards should not be undermined.
This is your task.

If we succeed in making that clear, then we are also sending a signal to the people who are protesting in their thousands, hundreds of thousands, these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a parliamentary group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
Where have we come to, that people experiencing profound social and personal distress can no longer receive any assistance or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here, we must finally become active.
And I would add one more point: an approach that prevails in the minds of many decision-makers is that the people in Greece and other countries have lived beyond their means.
You must be penalized today and must endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community based on solidarity.
I am not imputing that to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is pervasive in many countries and, unfortunately, recurs repeatedly in my own approach as well.
Mr. Chairman, I confess, I was mistaken.
I do not wish to offer an explanation for this report, but rather to address the report by Moreira concerning the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to request to be called again.

Madam President. The new directive establishes a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, musical pieces, and television productions that are subject to copyright, but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be found should be made available to the public.
And thus, a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was of particular importance in this legislative initiative to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union’s cultural heritage.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting corporations, there exist countless unused works, and they have hitherto been unavailable solely because the rights holder is unknown.
That changes with the directive.
It will enable the future utilization of this cultural asset, provided that a careful search is conducted prior to publication.
This is a very important point to prevent the casual assertion "We cannot locate the rights holder."
For a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the public’s need to be able to utilize such works where the legal situation could not be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be located, the draft enables the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects such as Europeana and other large European digitization initiatives, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasters, will flourish.
In the future, however, it must also address opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public as well.
This draft guideline and the compromise now found are, in my view, truly a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural heritage to which he belongs holds enormous potential.
We should continue to work on this during the revision of the guideline in two years as well. Thank you very much.
Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council. I would be pleased if, in proposal 2013, we also included clear
Signals from the Council would show us how we can develop growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we could provide employment for young people again.
Could you please inform us in which budgetary lines you are here promoting youth employment and prioritizing entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for that. I see here only cuts by the council.
or the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs or the programme for media pluralism—here, only cuts are made.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by implementing cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where is this to be found within the household report submitted by the council?
Nordseewerke in Emmen were compelled to file for insolvency last Wednesday, as a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with seven hundred qualified jobs, is undergoing a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

Now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass credit and that jobs can also be saved, because the seven hundred colleagues at SIAC and the Nordseewerken have already had to accept significant cuts concerning their wages.

Therefore, I request that the Commission examine this process favorably, but also promptly, so that these seven jobs are not jeopardized, as these seven jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues suffer as a result of the state government’s poor crisis management.
Dual-use goods often appear innocuous, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that facilitated the suppression of the Green Movement protests by Iranian security forces.
Protesters were mass-arrested, detained, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And this is just one example among many.
Furthermore, the Commission is also accused of promoting these questionable dual-use goods through its catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security industries.
The aim is to establish, as it were, a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy, quite literally selling off human rights, and also our security interests.
Therefore, I would like to request that you approve the proposed amendments from us and the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Ms. Regner, what do you believe trade unions could do, for example, to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will be insufficient.
What active role could the single market play here?
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that with today’s debate on MiFID we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
Within this legislative period, the focus has been on regulating financial markets, rather than merely considering individual products, as we have done in the past.
I would merely like to mention a few key points.
We certainly didn’t make things easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, questioning all stakeholders and interested parties, and, based on that, developed a result—through various processes, working documents, and the like—which we will present to the full assembly for a vote today and tomorrow.
I would like to highlight a few key points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must naturally acknowledge that considerable changes have occurred in the financial markets in recent years, and it is in the interest of Parliament to ensure that every transaction involving financial instruments takes place within the regulatory framework of MiFID. This is why we are, under many conditions, establishing a new category

who have agreed to the so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only Non-Equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is prohibited, and where, with regard to execution, transaction, and customer interaction, corresponding discretionary execution can take place.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire area of OTC papers that are traded is handled within the MiFID world.
Another significant topic that was not yet addressed in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, our aim was to establish clear rules of engagement, ensuring that this area—which can be very dangerous and can also be exploited for manipulative purposes—is subjected to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

with possibilities for trade interruptions, with the opportunity to test algorithms, with the opportunity for supervisory structures to examine algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price increment, and through appropriate fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of maintenance appointment markets.

I do believe that we have a particular responsibility here when it comes to restricting the speculative component in commodity futures markets, so as not to contribute, through flawed regulations, to a situation in which people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We have therefore opted for a two-pronged approach, with the aim of curbing speculation while not harming the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits on the number of contracts or positions, we aim to achieve this.

We also want to ensure, for those who can demonstrate a genuine need for a product, that they do not suddenly engage in speculative activity in this market as well, through a so-called Position Check System.
Another topic that occupies us considerably is the area of investor protection.
I would simply like to point out that we have adopted a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The purpose here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex instruments.

It concerns defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product reviews, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but – and I want to briefly mention this as well – to apply subsidiarity within the area of commissions.
Member States shall, in accordance with their structures, have the possibility to make corresponding adjustments.
I believe we are on the right track.
Upon the expiration of my time, I wish to thank all those who have contributed here.
I find it regrettable that one receives only four minutes of speaking time for such a complex dossier.
I would like to thank all colleagues who contributed here, and the committee for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.
I hope that, with a strong vote from the Plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter negotiations with the Council in order to finalize this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, thank you first of all for the overall good collaboration on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal, which had already taken significant steps in the right direction, in key areas.
Within the area of market structures, there will be greater transparency, more comprehensive transparency particularly in the field of derivative trading.

under the framework of MiFID. The resolutions in the area of high-frequency trading of our compromise go considerably further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
Even in areas that have drawn considerable public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, following extensive and difficult debates, it is now significantly stronger than the Commission’s resolutions, because position limits are enshrined there as binding.
We still require further adjustments in this area, however, to close any remaining gaps.
I also hope for further additions here through the plenary vote and ultimately also then in the trilogue.
It is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's more extensive proposal.
However, the report’s weaknesses lie in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to prohibit products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
To this day, the distribution of financial products is not primarily oriented toward the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product offers the highest commission.
Even in Germany, but throughout the EU, consumers have lost a great deal of money.
Think of the open-ended property funds.
For the citizens of France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be commission-based motivation.
To invoke subsidiarity here is somewhat facile.
Here, I would have wished for stricter regulations.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Yes, what takes a long time eventually turns out well, I can only say.
The report on the type approval of vehicles in category L has ultimately become a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped, and there were far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks once again to the rapporteur, Mr. van de Kamp, for his truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we were still able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend approving this report, although it could have been much better.
And with better, my very esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, vehicle safety and, consequently, safety for drivers—particularly the safety of scooter riders and motorcycle riders—have been paramount from the very beginning.
The number of motorcyclists injured in accidents, however, has remained constant for years.
In this case, the figures for fatalities in accidents generally decrease across Europe, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe’s roads – that was and that remains my goal.
Every deceased person is one too many.
Especially in a regulation so advantageous for the internal market, this topic must be addressed intensively.
I remain convinced that this can be achieved through effective technologies such as antilock braking systems, or ABS.
And I am equally convinced of its cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

We did, however, succeed in ensuring that from 2016, all new and, from 2017, all existing engine types with a displacement of 125 cubic centimeters or greater must be compulsorily equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
On scooters, manufacturers can equip them with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, we must regrettably concede that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission's proposal.
I had hoped for much more here, but the Commission and Member States have, to put it mildly, proved very cumbersome.
We did, however, manage to have the Commission present a report in 1919.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the member states and should investigate the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, this report will allow the Commission to consider making the installation of ABS in scooters mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will attempt to close the binding legislative gap beginning in 2019.
I am confident that the collected data will support my findings.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for riders of two-wheeled vehicles in Europe and that accident figures will decrease in the future. Thank you.
There is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
I believe that also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a newcomer in the energy markets through unconventional resources, specifically gas—primarily gas, but also oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to great euphoria regarding the vast gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint apocalyptic scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to fundamentally alter all existing energy supply relationships between providers and consumers, and that the economic viability calculations of previous energy sources are also being called into question.
We must confront the development.

I believe that we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to view and utilize new technologies positively, to weigh opportunities and risks fairly, and to avoid getting caught up in ideological debates.
Sir Inspector, your response does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a year to be a very long timeframe between the notification that a complaint has been received and potentially receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant, who has taken the trouble – and usually has already exhausted all legal avenues in their own member state – deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If you proceed in this manner, we will treat you accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and regulates rights clearly. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On a different point, I have no objection to attempting to achieve a kind of amicable clarification with the member state, provided it serves the purpose.
However, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe that it tends to proceed relatively quickly, for example, in economic matters, when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes, for example, to environmental issues and similar questions where a very, very large number of citizens demand the activity of the European Union, or also social rights, then the process proceeds somewhat more laboriously.
I believe that these facts, too, must be clearly considered.
I request that your next report include a clear formalization of the complainant’s rights vis-à-vis the Commission, rights that are genuinely unambiguous and effectively communicated.
If we truly want European law to be applied after we have adopted it through so many procedures here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
We have jointly decided. Then we must inform those who are responsible for it, those who are truly, so to speak, engaged at the European level, as accurately and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great concern to me.
And I will also carefully observe what has developed here again next time. Thank you.

Mr. President, colleagues,

Five years ago, the EU’s Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When assessing the balance sheet of this strategy today, the evaluation is ambivalent.

We observe how individual member states are striving for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region, while, on the other hand, progress is not being made in their efforts.
to accompany their transformation processes into modern democratic societies, or as recent events in Kazakhstan demonstrate, the development is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely because of this, the European Union and the Member States must express their influence more strongly together in this region, including and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only serve to allow competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country – to whom pressing for compliance with civil and human rights is of less importance – to assert their influence even more strongly than previously.
The linking of economic interests with the advocacy of citizen rights is the core element of the Central Asia Strategy.
This should also form the basis for the subsequent negotiations regarding a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.

The present report provides good orientation on this matter.
Thank you very much.

Madam President. Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament’s videostream, as you clearly have neither the capacity nor the inclination to speak with us live.
I regard the Council’s absence here and today as a gross disregard for Parliament.
Rather than avoiding this debate, you should instead reveal your reasoning for rejecting any improvement of the protection of personal data in the area of policing and justice through a directive.

Police and justice have for years – as we know – been an Eldorado of violations in data protection, not only concerning SWIFT, but for example daily, by unlawfully collecting and storing data of citizens who, for instance, demonstrate against Nazis.
We require equal protection standards for the public and private sectors, and for law enforcement and the judiciary; this is about guaranteeing civil rights.
If you, the Council, request that the Parliament constructively participate in data protection-relevant regulations such as EU PNA or Europol, then conversely, that must also apply to the Council.
Therefore, I urge you to finally end the policy of obstruction in the area of data protection.
